Notes for RL

0 - Terms that are used with different meaning

  1. Bootstrapping
    • Stats: resampling method.
    • RL: using existing estimates to form new targets.
  1. Return = cumulative (possibly discounted) sum of rewards from a time step.
  1. Backup = operation of updating an estimate by looking “back” at successor states (e.g. Bellman backup).
  1. Trajectory = sequence of (St,At,Rt+1)(S_t, A_t, R_{t+1})(St​,At​,Rt+1​)﻿ tuples from start until termination.
  1. Prediction = approximating the return under a fixed policy.
  1. Control = improving the policy toward optimality. (i.e. prediction + policy improvement).

Chapter 1 - Introduction

Concepts:

  • policy: the learning agent’s way of behaving at a given time.
  • reward signal: the goal of a reinforcement learning problem. On each time step, the environment sends to the reinforcement learning agent a single number called the reward. The agent’s sole objective is to maximize the total reward it receives over the long run.
  • value function: the value of a state is the total amount of reward an agent can expect to accumulate over the future, starting from that state. Whereas rewards determine the immediate, intrinsic desirability of environmental states, values indicate the long-term desirability of states after taking into account the states that are likely to follow and the rewards available in those states.
    For example, a state might always yield a low immediate reward but still have a high value because it is regularly followed by other states that yield high rewards.
  • model: For example, given a state and action, the model might predict the resultant next state and next reward.

Chapter 2 - Multi-armed Bandits

Activation-value Selection Methods

1. Greedy

Qt(a)≐sum of rewards when a taken prior to tnumber of times a taken prior to t=∑i=1t−1Ri⋅1Ai=a∑i=1t−11Ai=a,Q_t(a) \doteq \frac{\text{sum of rewards when $a$ taken prior to $t$}}{\text{number of times $a$ taken prior to $t$}} = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{t-1} R_i \cdot \mathbb{1}_{A_i=a}}{\sum_{i=1}^{t-1} \mathbb{1}_{A_i=a}},Qt​(a)≐number of times a taken prior to tsum of rewards when a taken prior to t​=∑i=1t−1​1Ai​=a​∑i=1t−1​Ri​⋅1Ai​=a​​,﻿

the greedy action selection is (to maximize the expectation) At≐arg⁡max⁡aQt(a)A_t \doteq \arg\max_a Q_t(a)At​≐argmaxa​Qt​(a)﻿.

near-greedy: In an ε-greedy method, the agent behaves greedily with probability 1-ε (i.e., it picks the action with the highest value), but occasionally (with probability ε), it selects an action randomly, regardless of the current value estimates.

to reduce memory while using sample-average action value estimation

(n denotes that it has been selected for times)

-> Qn+1=∑i=1nRi=Qn+1n[Rn−Qn]Q_{n+1} = \sum_{i=1}^n R_i= Q_n + \frac{1}{n}[R_n -Q_n]Qn+1​=∑i=1n​Ri​=Qn​+n1​[Rn​−Qn​]﻿

2. ε-Greedy

so for non-stationary case (where the step-size parameter α∈[0,1)\alpha \in [0, 1)α∈[0,1)﻿ is a constant):

Qt+1=Qt+α(Rt−Qt)=(1−α)tQ1+∑i=1tα(1−α)t−iRiQ_{t+1} = Q_t + \alpha \left( R_t - Q_t \right)= (1 - \alpha)^t Q_1 + \sum_{i=1}^{t} \alpha (1 - \alpha)^{t - i} R_iQt+1​=Qt​+α(Rt​−Qt​)=(1−α)tQ1​+∑i=1t​α(1−α)t−iRi​﻿

only apply to the chosen a, for the others Qt+1=QtQ_{t+1} = Q_tQt+1​=Qt​﻿

  • In the non-stationary case, the update uses a fixed step size α that doesn't depend on the number of times the action was chosen. What matters is time, not count — because the environment may change over time, and the agent needs to respond to recent changes.

compared with sample-average:

  • Recent rewards have more influence.
  • Old information is exponentially faded out.
  • The agent can adapt faster to changes in the environment.

for non-constant step-size,

Qt+1=(∏k=1t(1−αk))Q1+∑i=1t[αi∏j=i+1t(1−αj)]RiQ_{t+1} = \left( \prod_{k=1}^{t} (1 - \alpha_k) \right) Q_1 + \sum_{i=1}^{t} \left[ \alpha_i \prod_{j=i+1}^{t} (1 - \alpha_j) \right] R_iQt+1​=(∏k=1t​(1−αk​))Q1​+∑i=1t​[αi​∏j=i+1t​(1−αj​)]Ri​﻿

3. Upper-Confidence-Bound Action Selection (UCB)

At≐arg⁡max⁡a[Qt(a)+cln⁡tNt(a)]A_t \doteq \arg\max_a \left[ Q_t(a) + c \sqrt{\frac{\ln t}{N_t(a)}} \right]At​≐argmaxa​[Qt​(a)+cNt​(a)lnt​​]﻿
Intuition:

  • The term after c is called the exploration bonus.
  • If an action a hasn't been tried much (small Nt(a)), the bonus is large → encourages trying it.
  • As Nt(a) increases, the bonus shrinks → agent trusts the estimate Qt(a) more.
  • The formula balances:
    • Exploitation: pick actions with high Qt(a)
    • Exploration: try actions with high uncertainty

  • Preference Update Rule

(with baseline Rˉt \bar{R}_tRˉt​﻿, the average of all rewards up through and including time t)

For the selected action At=aA_t = aAt​=a﻿:

Ht+1(a)=Ht(a)+α(Rt−Rˉt)(1−πt(a))H_{t+1}(a) = H_t(a) + \alpha (R_t - \bar{R}_t) (1 - \pi_t(a))Ht+1​(a)=Ht​(a)+α(Rt​−Rˉt​)(1−πt​(a))﻿

Chapter 3 - Finite Markov Decision Process (MDP)

0. Markov Decision Process (MDP)

A Markov Decision Process (MDP) models the interaction between an agent and an environment over discrete time steps t=0,1,2,…t = 0, 1, 2, \dotst=0,1,2,…﻿ . At each time step:

  • The agent observes a state St∈SS_t \in \mathcal{S} St​∈S﻿ ,
  • Chooses an action At∈A(St)A_t \in \mathcal{A}(S_t) At​∈A(St​)﻿ ,
  • Receives a reward Rt+1∈RR_{t+1} \in \mathcal{R}Rt+1​∈R﻿ ,
  • And transitions to the next state St+1∈S S_{t+1} \in \mathcal{S} St+1​∈S﻿ .

A sequence of states, actions, and rewards forms a trajectory:
S0,A0,R1,S1,A1,R2,S2,A2,…S_0, A_0, R_1, S_1, A_1, R_2, S_2, A_2, \dotsS0​,A0​,R1​,S1​,A1​,R2​,S2​,A2​,…﻿

The dynamics of the environment are defined by the transition function:
p(s′,r∣s,a)≐Pr⁡{St=s′,Rt=r∣St−1=s,At−1=a},p(s', r \mid s, a) \doteq \Pr \{ S_t = s', R_t = r \mid S_{t-1} = s, A_{t-1} = a \}, p(s′,r∣s,a)≐Pr{St​=s′,Rt​=r∣St−1​=s,At−1​=a},﻿
which gives the probability of moving to state s′ s's′﻿ and receiving reward rrr﻿ when action aaa﻿ is taken in state sss﻿ .

The agent's goal is to maximize the expected return.

1. Returns>>

Sum of the future rewards

  • without discount

Gt=∑k=0∞Rt+k+1G_t = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} R_{t+k+1}Gt​=∑k=0∞​Rt+k+1​﻿

  • with discount γ∈[0,1)\gamma \in [0, 1)γ∈[0,1)﻿

Gt=∑k=0∞γkRt+k+1=Rt+1+γGt+1G_t = \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \gamma^k R_{t+k+1} = R_{t+1} + \gamma G_{t+1}Gt​=∑k=0∞​γkRt+k+1​=Rt+1​+γGt+1​﻿

Exercise

3.7 – Maze robot not learning

You give +1 for escaping, 0 elsewhere, and treat it as episodic. But the agent doesn’t learn to escape.

What’s going wrong>>

  • You only reward success, not progress.
  • If the agent never escapes, it gets all zero rewards, and it doesn’t know which actions are better or worse.
  • So the agent gets no learning signal from failure.

Fix>>

  • Add small negative rewards per time step (e.g., −0.01) to encourage faster escape.
  • This gives a shaping signal — incentive to try.

2. State-Value Function vπ(s)v_\pi(s)vπ​(s)﻿

The expected return (total discounted future reward) when starting from state s, and following policy π\piπ﻿.

vπ(s)≐Eπ[Gt∣St=s]=Eπ[∑k=0∞γkRt+k+1 | St=s]v_\pi(s) \doteq \mathbb{E}\pi \left[ G_t \mid S_t = s \right] = \mathbb{E}\pi \left[ \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \gamma^k R_{t+k+1} \,\middle|\, S_t = s \right]vπ​(s)≐Eπ[Gt​∣St​=s]=Eπ[∑k=0∞​γkRt+k+1​​St​=s]﻿

3. Action-Value Function qπ(s,a)q_\pi(s, a)qπ​(s,a)﻿

The expected return starting from state s, taking action a, and then following policy π.

qπ(s,a)≐Eπ[Gt∣St=s,At=a]=Eπ[∑k=0∞γkRt+k+1 | St=s,At=a]q_\pi(s, a) \doteq \mathbb{E}_\pi \left[ G_t \mid S_t = s, A_t = a \right] = \mathbb{E}_\pi \left[ \sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \gamma^k R_{t+k+1} \,\middle|\, S_t = s, A_t = a \right] qπ​(s,a)≐Eπ​[Gt​∣St​=s,At​=a]=Eπ​[∑k=0∞​γkRt+k+1​​St​=s,At​=a]﻿

Policy function π(s)\pi(s)π(s)﻿: the action to choose at state sss﻿

As we discussed above, even if we have a complete and accurate model of the environment’s dynamics, it is usually not possible to simply compute an optimal policy by solving the Bellman optimality equation.

Chapter 4 - Dynamic Programming

Policy Evaluation

To compute the state-value function vπv_\pivπ​﻿ for an arbitrary policy π\piπ﻿.

The relation ship is given in the Bellman equation.

But for large state spaces, solving this directly is tedious, so we use iteration:

  1. Start with an arbitrary guess v0v_0v0​﻿ (terminal states fixed at 0).
  1. Update repeatedly using the Bellman equation until convergence.

Update rule:

vk+1=Eπ[Rt+1+γvk(St+1)∣St=s]v_{k+1} = \mathbb{E}_\pi [R_{t+1} + \gamma v_k(S_{t+1})|S_t = s]vk+1​=Eπ​[Rt+1​+γvk​(St+1​)∣St​=s]﻿

=∑aπ(a∣s)∑s′,rp(s′,r∣s,a)[r+γ vk(s′)]= \sum_{a} \pi(a \mid s) \sum_{s', r} p(s', r \mid s, a) \left[ r + \gamma \, v_k(s') \right]=∑a​π(a∣s)∑s′,r​p(s′,r∣s,a)[r+γvk​(s′)]﻿

The pseudocode that sweep over different s:

Policy Improvement

Action-value under π
qπ(s,a)=E[Rt+1+γVπ(St+1)∣St=s,At=a]q_\pi(s,a) = \mathbb{E}\left[ R_{t+1} + \gamma V_\pi(S_{t+1}) \mid S_t = s, A_t = a \right]qπ​(s,a)=E[Rt+1​+γVπ​(St+1​)∣St​=s,At​=a]﻿


Now make a greedy policy
π′(s)∈arg⁡max⁡a  qπ(s,a)\pi'(s) \in \arg\max_a \; q_\pi(s,a)π′(s)∈argmaxa​qπ​(s,a)﻿,

Policy Improvement Theorem: this choice never makes things worse:
vπ′(s)≥vπ(s)∀sv_{\pi'}(s) \ge v_\pi(s) \quad \forall svπ′​(s)≥vπ​(s)∀s﻿,

with strict > somewhere if the argmax is unique and π wasn’t already greedy.

Intuition: if you know the long‑term value of each action under π, picking the best one in each state cannot reduce the return.

Policy Iteration:

Alternate evaluate and improve until the policy stops changing.

Policy Evaluation (Bellman expectation for VπV_\piVπ​﻿
Vπ(s)=∑aπ(a∣s)∑s′,rp(s′,r∣s,a)[r+γVπ(s′)]V_\pi(s) = \sum_a \pi(a \mid s) \sum_{s',r} p(s',r \mid s,a) \left[ r + \gamma V_\pi(s') \right]Vπ​(s)=∑a​π(a∣s)∑s′,r​p(s′,r∣s,a)[r+γVπ​(s′)]﻿

Policy Iteration (improvement step in model form)
πk+1(s)∈arg⁡max⁡a∑s′,rp(s′,r∣s,a)[r+γVπk(s′)]\pi_{k+1}(s) \in \arg\max_a \sum_{s',r} p(s',r \mid s,a) \left[ r + \gamma V_{\pi_k}(s') \right]πk+1​(s)∈argmaxa​∑s′,r​p(s′,r∣s,a)[r+γVπk​​(s′)]﻿


In finite MDPs, this converges in finitely many steps to an optimal policy

Value Iteration

  • We don’t need exact VπV_\piVπ​﻿ to pick the same greedy action we’d pick with the exact one.
  • As long as our current VV V﻿ is “close enough” to the real VπV_\piVπ​﻿, the greedy step will still choose the optimal action for that policy.
  • The extreme case — one sweep per outer loop — merges evaluation and improvement into a single step.

Asynchronous Dynamic Programming

In asynchronous DP:

  • Update states one-by-one,
  • An updated state can immediately influence the next state’s computation in the same iteration,
  • We don’t need to visit states in a fixed sequence

We have a 3-state MDP S={A,B,C}S = \{A,B,C\}S={A,B,C}﻿ and deterministic transitions:

The Bellman optimality equation is:

v(s)←max⁡a[r(s,a)+γv(s′)]v(s) \gets \max_a \left[ r(s,a) + \gamma v(s') \right]v(s)←maxa​[r(s,a)+γv(s′)]﻿

Synchronous update example

Iteration 2:

Repeat the above for all states again using the updated values from iteration 1.

Asynchronous update example

Start with:

v(A)=v(B)=v(C)=0v(A) = v(B) = v(C) = 0v(A)=v(B)=v(C)=0﻿

Step 1:

v(A)←5+v(B)=5v(A) \gets 5 + v(B) = 5v(A)←5+v(B)=5﻿

Step 2:

v(B)←2+v(C)=2v(B) \gets 2 + v(C) = 2v(B)←2+v(C)=2﻿

Step 3:

v(A)←5+v(B)=5+2=7v(A) \gets 5 + v(B) = 5 + 2 = 7v(A)←5+v(B)=5+2=7﻿

And so on.

Generalized Policy Iteration

We use the term generalized policy iteration (GPI) to refer to the general idea of letting policy-evaluation and policy improvement processes interact, independent of the granularity and other details of the two processes.

Efficiency

If we ignore a few technical details, then the (worst case) time DP methods take to find an optimal policy is polynomial in the number of states and actions. If nnn﻿ and kk k﻿ denote the number of states and actions, this means that a DP method takes a number of computational operations that is less than some polynomial function of n and kkk﻿. A DP method is guaranteed to find an optimal policy in polynomial time even though the total number of (deterministic) policies is knk^nkn﻿.

Summary

  • Policy evaluation refers to the (typically) iterative computation of the value functions for a given policy.
  • Policy improvement refers to the computation of an improved policy given the value function for that policy.


Putting these two computations together, we obtain policy iteration and value iteration, the two most popular DP methods. Either of these can be used to reliably compute optimal policies and value functions for finite MDPs given complete knowledge of the MDP.

Chapter 5 - Monte Carlo Methods

  • Do not assume complete knowledge of the environment,
  • Requires only experience —sample sequences of states, actions, and rewards from actual or simulated interaction with an environment.
  • Although a model is required, the model need only generate sample transitions, not the complete probability distributions of all possible transitions that is required for dynamic programming (DP).

Suppose we want to estimate vπ(s)v_\pi(s)vπ​(s)﻿ (the value of a state sss﻿ under policy π\piπ﻿). Giving a set of episodes obtained by following π\piπ﻿ and passing through sss﻿. Each occurrence of state sss﻿ in an episode is called a visit to sss﻿. Then we can define>

  • The first visit to sss﻿: the first time sss﻿ is visited in an episode.
  • Then first visit MC method (unbiased) : is a way to estimate the value function for a given policy π\piπ﻿ by averaging actual returns from sampled episodes, but only using the first time a state appears in each episode.

We want: vπ(s)=Eπ[Gt∣St=s]v_\pi(s) = \mathbb{E}_\pi \left[ G_t \mid S_t = s \right]vπ​(s)=Eπ​[Gt​∣St​=s]﻿, where GtG_tGt​﻿ is the return from time ttt﻿ onward in the episode.

In each episode:

  1. Follow the policy π \piπ﻿ from some starting state until the episode ends.
  1. For each state sss﻿ that appears in the episode, find the first time step ttt﻿ at which sss﻿ is visited.
  1. Compute the return GtG_tGt​﻿ from that first occurrence to the end of the episode.
  1. Record GtG_tGt​﻿ in a list for state sss﻿.
  1. At the end (or as you go), estimate vπ(s)v_\pi(s)vπ​(s)﻿ as the average of all these first-visit returns.

Example

Suppose we run a policy in an episodic gridworld, and an episode looks like:

S0=A,S1=B,S2=C,S3=B,S4=TerminalS_0 = A, \quad S_1 = B, \quad S_2 = C, \quad S_3 = B, \quad S_4 = \text{Terminal}S0​=A,S1​=B,S2​=C,S3​=B,S4​=Terminal﻿

Rewards: R1=0,  R2=1,  R3=−1,  R4=0R_1 = 0, \; R_2 = 1, \; R_3 = -1, \; R_4 = 0R1​=0,R2​=1,R3​=−1,R4​=0﻿

Discount: γ=1\gamma = 1γ=1﻿

First-visit times:

  • AAA﻿: t=0t=0t=0﻿, G0=0+1+(−1)+0=0G_0 = 0 + 1 + (-1) + 0 = 0G0​=0+1+(−1)+0=0﻿
  • BBB﻿: first at t=1t=1t=1﻿, G1=1+(−1)+0=0G_1 = 1 + (-1) + 0 = 0G1​=1+(−1)+0=0﻿ (ignore BBB﻿ at t=3t=3t=3﻿)
  • CCC﻿: first at t=2t=2t=2﻿, G2=−1+0=−1G_2 = -1 + 0 = -1G2​=−1+0=−1﻿

We’d add these returns to our record for A,B,CA, B, CA,B,C﻿ and average over many episodes.

  • Estimation of Action Values

Under the given π\piπ﻿ approximate the action-value function.

Monte Carlo Control

Key: Generalized Policy Iteration (GPI)

  • Maintain both:
    • An approximate policy π\piπ﻿
    • An approximate action-value function QQQ﻿
  • Alternate between:
    1. Policy evaluation: use MC to estimate qπ(s,a)q_\pi(s,a)qπ​(s,a)﻿ for the current π\piπ
    1. Policy improvement: update π\piπ﻿ to be greedy w.r.t. the current QQQ﻿
  • These steps run repeatedly; each step changes the target for the other, but together they converge toward optimal policy and value function.

Monte Carlo version of Policy Iteration

Start from some policy π0\pi_0π0​﻿:

π0⇒Eqπ0⇒Iπ1⇒Eqπ1⇒Iπ2 … ⇒Iπ∗⇒Eq∗.\pi_0 \xRightarrow{\text{E}} q_{\pi_0} \xRightarrow{\text{I}} \pi_1 \xRightarrow{\text{E}} q_{\pi_1} \xRightarrow{\text{I}} \pi_2 \ \dots \ \xRightarrow{\text{I}} \pi_* \xRightarrow{\text{E}} q_* .π0​E​qπ0​​I​π1​E​qπ1​​I​π2​ … I​π∗​E​q∗​.﻿

  • E = complete policy evaluation via MC estimation of qπq_\piqπ​﻿
  • I = complete policy improvement by making π\piπ﻿ greedy w.r.t. QQQ﻿

Greedy policy

Given q(s,a)q(s,a)q(s,a)﻿, the greedy policy is:

π(s)≐arg⁡max⁡aq(s,a)\pi(s) \doteq \arg\max_a q(s,a)π(s)≐argmaxa​q(s,a)﻿

This picks the action with the highest estimated return from each state.

No model is required because q(s,a)q(s,a)q(s,a)﻿ is learned directly from experience.

Assumptions here (Not feasible)

  • Infinite episodes (enough data for convergence)
  • Exploring starts — every (s,a)(s,a)(s,a)﻿ pair has a nonzero chance to start an episode, ensuring all state–action pairs are visited.

Remark:

This is inefficient because for each state–action pair, it maintains a list of all returns and repeatedly calculates their mean. It would be more efficient to only maintain the mean and a count like we introduced in Chapter 2.

Also it’s not feasible since each episode begins from a randomly chosen state–action pair with nonzero probability for all pairs (thus the probability of being visit infinitely is guaranteed for every pair ). But this is unrealistic in many real problems — you often can’t start in arbitrary (s,a). (s,a).(s,a).﻿

>>On policy MC

  • Episode start: start from whatever the environment naturally gives you (initial state distribution).
  • Exploration: ensure every action has nonzero probability under the current policy — typically use an ε\varepsilonε﻿-soft policy: π(a∣s)≥ε∣A(s)∣\pi(a|s) \ge \frac{\varepsilon}{|A(s)|}π(a∣s)≥∣A(s)∣ε​﻿ for all actions aaa﻿.
  • Policy improvement: move toward greedy but keep ε\varepsilonε﻿-softness (so exploration continues).
  • Advantage:
    • Works in realistic environments where you can’t choose starting state/action.
  • Drawback:
    • Policy never becomes fully greedy — it keeps a small amount of randomization.

Now we only achieve the best policy among the "-soft policies, but on the other hand, we have eliminated the assumption of exploring starts.

Off-policy Prediction via Importance Sampling

We have two policies:

  • Target policy π\piπ﻿ → the one we want to evaluate (find vπ(s)v_\pi(s)vπ​(s)﻿)
  • Behavior policy bbb﻿ → the one we actually follow to collect episodes

In this case we say that learning is from data “off” the target policy, and the overall process is termed off-policy learning.

Importance sampling ratio

For one full episode starting at time ttt﻿:

ρt:T−1=∏k=tT−1π(Ak∣Sk)b(Ak∣Sk)\rho_{t:T-1} = \prod_{k=t}^{T-1} \frac{\pi(A_k \mid S_k)}{b(A_k \mid S_k)}ρt:T−1​=∏k=tT−1​b(Ak​∣Sk​)π(Ak​∣Sk​)​﻿

  • If bbb﻿ and π\piπ﻿ are the same → ratio = 1
  • If they differ → ratio > 1 or < 1 depending on the likelihoods
  • If bbb﻿ takes an action that π\piπ﻿ would never take → ratio = 0 (episode useless for π\piπ﻿)

Estimating vπ(s)v_\pi(s)vπ​(s)﻿

For each time you see state sss﻿ in episodes generated by bbb﻿:

  1. Compute GtG_tGt​﻿ = actual return from that state onward
  1. Multiply it by the ratio ρt:T−1\rho_{t:T-1}ρt:T−1​﻿
  1. Average over all such weighted returns (unstable)

vπ(s)≈∑ρt:T−1Gt# of samplesv_\pi(s) \approx \frac{\sum \rho_{t:T-1} G_t}{\text{\# of samples}}vπ​(s)≈# of samples∑ρt:T−1​Gt​​﻿

(or weighted version to reduce variance —> faster convergence)

vπ(s)≈∑ρt:T−1Gt∑ρt:T−1v_\pi(s) \approx \frac{\sum \rho_{t:T-1} G_t}{\sum \rho_{t:T-1}}vπ​(s)≈∑ρt:T−1​∑ρt:T−1​Gt​​﻿

We need only consider episodes that involve some number (possibly zero) of left actions that transition back to the nonterminal state, followed by a left action transitioning to termination. All of these episodes have a return of 1, so the G0 factor can be ignored. To get the expected square we need only consider each length of episode, multiplying the probability of the episode’s occurrence by the square of its importance-sampling ratio, and add these up:

Incremental Implementation

Without storing the full returns.

  • Ordinary importance sampling
    • Just scale the returns GGG﻿ by the importance ratio ρ\rhoρ and average them.
    • You can directly use the incremental average update from Ch. 2 :

      V←V+1n(ρG−V)V \leftarrow V + \frac{1}{n}( \rho G - V )V←V+n1​(ρG−V)﻿

      (a average over all samples → incrementally add each term one by one)

      (or constant step size for non-stationary problems).

  • Weighted importance sampling (focus here)
    • Estimator formula:

      Vn=∑k=1n−1WkGk∑k=1n−1WkV_n = \frac{\sum_{k=1}^{n-1} W_k G_k}{\sum_{k=1}^{n-1} W_k}Vn​=∑k=1n−1​Wk​∑k=1n−1​Wk​Gk​​﻿

      where WkW_kWk​﻿ is the weight (importance ratio) for return GkG_kGk​﻿.

    • Incremental update:

      Vn+1=Vn+WnCn[Gn−Vn]V_{n+1} = V_n + \frac{W_n}{C_n} \big[ G_n - V_n \big]Vn+1​=Vn​+Cn​Wn​​[Gn​−Vn​]﻿

      where:

      • CnC_nCn​﻿ = cumulative sum of weights WWW﻿ up to step nnn﻿,
      • Cn←Cn+Wn+1C_{n} \leftarrow C_n + W_{n+1}Cn​←Cn​+Wn+1​﻿, C0=0C_0 = 0C0​=0﻿.

Off-policy Monte-Carlo Control

A potential problem is that this method learns only from the tails of episodes, when all of the remaining actions in the episode are greedy. If nongreedy actions are common, then learning will be slow, particularly for states appearing in the early portions of long episodes. Potentially, this could greatly slow learning.

Chapter 6 - Temporal-Difference Methods

TD(0)

TD(0) (one-step temporal-difference learning), the simplest TD method.

  • Monte Carlo (MC) must wait until the end of an episode to compute the full return GtG_tGt​﻿ and update V(St)V(S_t)V(St​)﻿.
  • TD(0) updates V(St)V(S_t)V(St​)﻿ immediately after seeing the reward Rt+1R_{t+1}Rt+1​﻿ and the next state St+1S_{t+1}St+1​﻿.
  • The target for TD(0) is: Rt+1+γV(St+1)R_{t+1} + \gamma V(S_{t+1})Rt+1​+γV(St+1​)﻿
  • This allows online learning without waiting for episode termination.

Update rule>>

V(St)←V(St)+α[Rt+1+γV(St+1)−V(St)]V(S_t) \leftarrow V(S_t) + \alpha \left[ R_{t+1} + \gamma V(S_{t+1}) - V(S_t) \right]V(St​)←V(St​)+α[Rt+1​+γV(St+1​)−V(St​)]﻿

Batch Updating >>

Instead of updating V(St)V(S_t)V(St​)﻿ immediately after each step (online update), you collect all transitions from a batch of episodes first, and then update the value function repeatedly until it is consistent with that batch.

Sarsa

— on policy TD control method.

State, Action, Reward, State, Action.

  • In control, instead of estimating only state values vπ(s)v_\pi(s)vπ​(s)﻿, we estimate action values qπ(s,a)q_\pi(s,a)qπ​(s,a)﻿ for the current policy π\piπ﻿
  • For on-policy methods, we update qπ(s,a)q_\pi(s,a)qπ​(s,a)﻿ based on the actions actually taken by the behavior policy π\piπ﻿.
  • The update is based on TD(0) logic, but applied to state–action pairs instead of just states.

Key idea:

  • An episode is a sequence: St,At,Rt+1,St+1,At+1,Rt+2,…S_t, A_t, R_{t+1}, S_{t+1}, A_{t+1}, R_{t+2}, \dotsSt​,At​,Rt+1​,St+1​,At+1​,Rt+2​,…﻿
  • The TD update for action values is:

Q(St,At)  ←  Q(St,At)+α[Rt+1+γQ(St+1,At+1)−Q(St,At)]Q(S_t, A_t) \;\leftarrow\; Q(S_t, A_t) + \alpha \left[ R_{t+1} + \gamma Q(S_{t+1}, A_{t+1}) - Q(S_t, A_t) \right]Q(St​,At​)←Q(St​,At​)+α[Rt+1​+γQ(St+1​,At+1​)−Q(St​,At​)]﻿

  • This rule uses every quintuple (St,At,Rt+1,St+1,At+1(S_t, A_t, R_{t+1}, S_{t+1}, A_{t+1}(St​,At​,Rt+1​,St+1​,At+1​﻿) observed in the episode.

Expected Sarsa

Q-learning

Off-policy TD control: the learned action-value function directly approximates q∗q^{*}q∗﻿ , independent of the policy being followed.

The update>>

Q(St,At)  ←  Q(St,At)+α[Rt+1+γQ(St+1,a)−Q(St,At)]Q(S_t, A_t) \;\leftarrow\; Q(S_t, A_t) + \alpha \left[ R_{t+1} + \gamma Q(S_{t+1}, a) - Q(S_t, A_t) \right]Q(St​,At​)←Q(St​,At​)+α[Rt+1​+γQ(St+1​,a)−Q(St​,At​)]﻿

compare with Sarsa: max⁡aQ(St+1,a)\max_{a} Q(S_{t+1}, a)maxa​Q(St+1​,a)﻿ instead of Q(St+1,At+1)Q(S_{t+1}, A_{t+1})Q(St+1​,At+1​)﻿

Maximization Bias and Double Learning

max⁡\maxmax﻿ in Sarsa and Q-learning: might lead to a significant positive bias.

Example>> Maximum bias

The small MDP shown inset in Figure provides a simple example of how maximization bias can harm the performance of TD control algorithms. The MDP has two non-terminal states A and B. Episodes always start in A with a choice between two actions, left and right. The right action transitions immediately to the terminal state with a reward and return of zero. The left action transitions to B, also with a reward of zero, from which there are many possible actions all of which cause immediate termination with a reward drawn from a normal distribution with mean −0.1 and variance 1.0. Thus, the expected return for any trajectory starting with left is −0.1, and thus taking left in state A is always a mistake.

Nevertheless, our control methods may favor left because of maximization bias making B appear to have a positive value. Figure 6.5 shows that Q-learning with ε-greedy action selection initially learns to strongly favor the left action on this example. Even at asymptote, Q-learning takes the left action about 5% more often than is optimal at our parameter settings (ε = 0.1, α = 0.1, and γ = 1).

Double learning>>(double Q-learning)

Learn 2 independent estimates QAQ_AQA​﻿, QBQ_BQB​﻿.

Update one of the tables with prob 1/2:

  • If we update QAQ^AQA﻿:

QA(St,At) ⁣← ⁣QA(St,At)+α[Rt+1+γ QB ⁣(St+1, arg⁡max⁡aQA(St+1,a))−QA(St,At)].Q^A(S_t,A_t)\!\leftarrow\! Q^A(S_t,A_t) + \alpha\Big[ R_{t+1} + \gamma\, Q^B\!\big(S_{t+1},\, \arg\max_a Q^A(S_{t+1},a)\big) - Q^A(S_t,A_t)\Big].QA(St​,At​)←QA(St​,At​)+α[Rt+1​+γQB(St+1​,argmaxa​QA(St+1​,a))−QA(St​,At​)].﻿

  • If we update QBQ^BQB﻿: swap AAA﻿ and BBB﻿.

(For Double SARSA—on-policy—you’d pick A′∼πA'\sim\piA′∼π﻿ at St+1S_{t+1}St+1​﻿ and evaluate with the other table:

Rt+1+γ QB(St+1,A′)R_{t+1}+\gamma\,Q^B(S_{t+1},A')Rt+1​+γQB(St+1​,A′)﻿ when updating QAQ^AQA﻿, and vice versa.)

Chapter 7 - n-step Bootstrapping

Monte Carlo methods perform an update for each state based on the entire sequence of observed rewards from that state until the end of the episode. The update of one-step TD methods, on the other
hand, is based on just the one next reward, bootstrapping from the value of the state one step later as a proxy for the remaining rewards.

One kind of intermediate method>> perform an update based on an intermediate number of rewards: more than one, but less than all of them until termination.

E.g. n-steps TD methods - For example, a two-step update would be based on the first two rewards and the estimated value of the state two steps later.
Similarly, we could have three-step updates, four-step updates, and so on. for the multi-step TD,

n-steps TD Prediction

Complete return (Monte Carlo target)

The full return from time ttt﻿ until the end of the episode is

Gt≐Rt+1+γRt+2+γ2Rt+3+⋯+γT−t−1RT,G_t \doteq R_{t+1} + \gamma R_{t+2} + \gamma^2 R_{t+3} + \cdots + \gamma^{T-t-1} R_T,Gt​≐Rt+1​+γRt+2​+γ2Rt+3​+⋯+γT−t−1RT​,﻿ where TTT﻿ is the final time step of the episode.

This is what Monte Carlo methods use as the target.

1. One-step return (TD target)

Plain Sarsa and Q-leaning are both 1-step return

Instead of waiting until the end, we can bootstrap after 1 reward:

Gt:t+1≐Rt+1+γVt(St+1),G_{t:t+1} \doteq R_{t+1} + \gamma V_t(S_{t+1}),Gt:t+1​≐Rt+1​+γVt​(St+1​),﻿

where VtV_tVt​﻿ is our current estimate of the value function.

2. Two-step return

We can generalize this to 2 steps of real rewards, then bootstrap:

Gt:t+2≐Rt+1+γRt+2+γ2Vt+1(St+2).G_{t:t+2} \doteq R_{t+1} + \gamma R_{t+2} + \gamma^2 V_{t+1}(S_{t+2}).Gt:t+2​≐Rt+1​+γRt+2​+γ2Vt+1​(St+2​).﻿

Here the bootstrapped value Vt+1(St+2)V_{t+1}(S_{t+2})Vt+1​(St+2​)﻿ replaces the rest of the return.

3. General n-step return

The n-step return is:

Gt:t+n≐Rt+1+γRt+2+⋯+γn−1Rt+n+γnVt+n−1(St+n).G_{t:t+n} \doteq R_{t+1} + \gamma R_{t+2} + \cdots + \gamma^{n-1} R_{t+n} + \gamma^n V_{t+n-1}(S_{t+n}).Gt:t+n​≐Rt+1​+γRt+2​+⋯+γn−1Rt+n​+γnVt+n−1​(St+n​).﻿

  • If n=1n = 1n=1﻿, this reduces to the TD(0) target.
  • If n→∞n \to \inftyn→∞﻿, this becomes the full Monte Carlo return.

4. n-step TD update rule

The value function is updated as

Vt+n(St)≐Vt+n−1(St)+α[Gt:t+n−Vt+n−1(St)],V_{t+n}(S_t) \doteq V_{t+n-1}(S_t) + \alpha \Big[ G_{t:t+n} - V_{t+n-1}(S_t) \Big],Vt+n​(St​)≐Vt+n−1​(St​)+α[Gt:t+n​−Vt+n−1​(St​)],﻿ 0≤t<T0 \leq t < T0≤t<T﻿.

This is called the n-step TD algorithm.

>>no changes at all are made during the first (n-1) steps of each episode. To make up for that, an equal number of additional updates are made at the end of the episode, after termination and before starting the next episode.

n-step Sarsa

Chapter 8 - Planning and Learning with Tabular Methods

Dyna-Q

• Dyna-Q: real samples + simulated samples from a learned model, both updated with the same Q-learning rule.

Dyna-Q (hybrid)

Combine Q-learning and ground truth planning by taking the simulated examples as known dynamic.

  1. Real step:

    Update QQQ﻿ using real experience (same as Q-learning).

  1. Model step:

    Store transition (s,a)↦(r,s′)(s,a)\mapsto(r,s')(s,a)↦(r,s′)﻿.

  1. Planning step (simulated experience):

    Sample (s^,a^)(\hat{s}, \hat{a})(s^,a^)﻿ from the model, get (r^,s^′)(\hat{r},\hat{s}')(r^,s^′)﻿, and apply the same Q-learning update:

    Q(s^,a^)  ←  Q(s^,a^)+α[r^+γmax⁡a′Q(s^′,a′)−Q(s^,a^)].Q(\hat{s},\hat{a}) \;\leftarrow\; Q(\hat{s},\hat{a}) + \alpha \Big[ \hat{r} + \gamma \max_{a'} Q(\hat{s}',a') - Q(\hat{s},\hat{a}) \Big].Q(s^,a^)←Q(s^,a^)+α[r^+γmaxa′​Q(s^′,a′)−Q(s^,a^)].﻿

In practice:

Episode 1>>> no planning step, plain Q-learning

Episode 2+>>use the result from Episode 1 to perform several planning steps (e.g. 5, 10, 50, ..)

How to implement

  1. Real interaction (per time step):
    • The agent takes an action in the real environment, observes (s,a,r,s′)(s,a,r,s')(s,a,r,s′)﻿.
    • Perform a normal Q-learning update.
    • Store this transition in the model (memory).
  1. Planning (right after the real step):
    • For nnn﻿ times, sample some past (s^,a^)(\hat{s}, \hat{a})(s^,a^)﻿ from the model.
    • Use the stored (r^,s^′)(\hat{r}, \hat{s}')(r^,s^′)﻿ to do a Q-learning update as if it were real.
  1. Repeat until the episode ends.

BUT>>

In basic Dyna-Q, when doing planning updates, you pick state–action pairs randomly from the model memory.

  • This means you might waste time replaying transitions that don’t matter much right now.
  • Example: If a reward has just been discovered, you’d like to propagate that reward quickly back through all the states that lead to it — not spend time updating some unrelated corner of the maze.

Solution>>Prioritized Sweeping

Transferable?

Trajectory Sampling

In this section we compare two ways of distributing updates. The classical approach, from dynamic programming, is to perform sweeps through the entire state (or state–action) space, updating each state (or state–action pair) once per sweep. This is problematic on large tasks because there may not be time to complete even one sweep. In many tasks the vast majority of the states are irrelevant because they are visited only under very poor policies or with very low probability.

  • Dyna-Q: planning is local : after a real step, you pick some stored state–action pairs and do one-step Q-learning updates.
  • Trajectory sampling: planning is global: you simulate full rollouts from the model, often guided by the current policy, and update as if they were real.

  • Dyna: replays individual learned transitions (local updates).
  • Trajectory sampling: chains those learned transitions together to form full rollouts. In both cases, if you haven’t learned anything yet, the model is empty no planning is possible. But as soon as the model has some entries, you can begin trajectory sampling from states where you know at least one transition.

Tabular Methods - Conclusion

Prediction — To get the value function.

Control — To get the policy.

  • Base methods: TD(0), SARSA, Q-learning.
  • Variance/accuracy fixes: Expected SARSA, Double Q-learning.
  • Longer horizons: n-step, TD(λ).
  • Model-based: Dyna-Q, Prioritized sweeping.

Once the state space grows (to infinity), we move to function approximation (deep RL).

1. Policy Evaluation (Prediction only)

  • Goal: estimate value of a fixed policy π\piπ﻿.
  • Methods:
    • Monte Carlo (MC): average returns after full episodes.
      • Pros: unbiased, simple.
      • Cons: need full episodes, high variance.
    • TD(0): bootstraps from next state’s value V(St+1)V(S_{t+1})V(St+1​)﻿.
      • Pros: online, lower variance.
      • Cons: biased.
    • n-step TD: interpolate between MC (n=episode) and TD(0) (n=1).
    • TD(λ): exponential averaging over all nnn﻿-step returns.

2. Control (Learning a good policy)

On-policy control

  • Learn while following the same policy you’re evaluating/improving.
  • SARSA (1-step TD control):

    Q(s,a)←Q(s,a)+α(r+γQ(s′,a′)−Q(s,a))Q(s,a) \gets Q(s,a) + \alpha \big( r + \gamma Q(s',a') - Q(s,a)\big)Q(s,a)←Q(s,a)+α(r+γQ(s′,a′)−Q(s,a))﻿

    → Learns value of the ϵ\epsilonϵ﻿-greedy policy actually followed.

  • Expected SARSA: use expected value over actions instead of sampled a′a'a′﻿.

    → Less variance, more stable.

  • n-step SARSA: update using longer returns.
  • SARSA(λ): λ-return version.

Off-policy control

  • Learn about a greedy/target policy while following a different (exploratory) behavior policy.
  • Q-learning:

    Q(s,a)←Q(s,a)+α(r+γmax⁡a′Q(s′,a′)−Q(s,a))Q(s,a) \gets Q(s,a) + \alpha \big( r + \gamma \max_{a'} Q(s',a') - Q(s,a)\big)Q(s,a)←Q(s,a)+α(r+γmaxa′​Q(s′,a′)−Q(s,a))﻿

    → Off-policy, learns optimal policy directly.

  • Double Q-learning: two Q-tables to reduce overestimation bias.

3. Adding a Model (Planning)

  • Learn a model of transitions & rewards, then update “as if” from imagination.
  • Dyna-Q:
    • Mix real experience updates with simulated updates from the model.
  • Prioritized sweeping:
    • Instead of random simulated updates, maintain a priority queue of states with large TD error → update them first.
    • Much more sample-efficient.

UCB in Tabuler Methods

So in your UCB rule you should really use

arg⁡max⁡a[Q(s,a)  +  cln⁡N(s)N(s,a)],\arg\max_a \Big[ Q(s,a) \;+\; c \sqrt{\tfrac{\ln N(s)}{N(s,a)}} \Big],argmaxa​[Q(s,a)+cN(s,a)lnN(s)​​],﻿

where

  • N(s)=∑aN(s,a)N(s) = \sum_a N(s,a)N(s)=∑a​N(s,a)﻿ = total visits to state s,
  • N(s,a)N(s,a)N(s,a)﻿ = visits to that action from that state,
  • c = exploration coefficient.

Chapter 9 - On-policy Prediction with Approximation

Value-function approximation

All prediction methods (MC, TD, DP, n-step, etc.) can be described as: s↦us \mapsto us↦u﻿

meaning:

  • You update the estimated value at state sss﻿.
  • You push it a bit toward some update target uuu﻿.

Examples:

  • Monte Carlo: u=Gtu = G_tu=Gt​﻿ (full return).
  • TD(0): u=Rt+1+γV(St+1)u = R_{t+1} + \gamma V(S_{t+1})u=Rt+1​+γV(St+1​)﻿.
  • n-step TD: u=Gt:t+nu = G_{t:t+n}u=Gt:t+n​﻿.
  • DP policy evaluation: u=E[Rt+1+γV(St+1)∣St=s]u = \mathbb{E}[R_{t+1} + \gamma V(S_{t+1}) \mid S_t=s]u=E[Rt+1​+γV(St+1​)∣St​=s]﻿.

Tabular case

  • In tabular methods, updating s↦us \mapsto us↦u﻿ means: directly adjust the table entry V(s)V(s)V(s)﻿ toward uuu﻿.
  • Only that state changes; others are unaffected.
  • Simple and exact if state space is small.

Function approximation interpretation

  • With approximation, we can’t just overwrite one cell.
  • Instead, we treat each (s,u)(s,u)(s,u)﻿ as a training example:
    “When the input is sss﻿, the output should be close to uuu﻿.”
  • This is exactly like supervised learning (input–output regression).
  • The function (NN, linear model, etc.) is trained on these pairs, producing V^\hat VV^﻿ that generalizes to unseen states.

Challenges

  • In normal supervised learning, training data is static.

    In RL, data arrives sequentially and the agent must learn online.

  • Targets uuu﻿ are nonstationary:
    • They change as policy π\piπ﻿ changes (in control).
    • They change because they are bootstrapped from current estimates (in TD/DP).
  • So RL needs function approximators that can handle:
    • Online, incremental updates.
    • Moving targets.

Not all ML models can do this well (e.g., batch-trained methods without incremental learning struggle).

The prediction objective VE‾\overline{VE}VE﻿

We need to define the object and error of prediction for learning methods:

Defining the error

We introduce a weighting distribution μ(s)\mu(s)μ(s)﻿ (probability over states):

  • μ(s)≥0\mu(s) \ge 0μ(s)≥0﻿, ∑sμ(s)=1\sum_s \mu(s) = 1∑s​μ(s)=1﻿.
  • Tells us how much we care about accuracy in each state.
    • Example: time spent in sss﻿ under the current policy.

Error at a single state: vπ(s)−v^(s,w).v_\pi(s) - \hat v(s, \mathbf{w}).vπ​(s)−v^(s,w).﻿

Square it and average over all states using μ\muμ﻿:

Mean Squared Value Error (VE):

VE‾(w)=∑s∈Sμ(s)[vπ(s)−v^(s,w)]2.\overline{VE}(\mathbf{w}) = \sum_{s \in \mathcal{S}} \mu(s)\big[v_\pi(s) - \hat v(s, \mathbf{w})\big]^2.VE(w)=∑s∈S​μ(s)[vπ​(s)−v^(s,w)]2.﻿

VE‾\overline{VE}VE﻿ is good, but usually we dont know the vπ(s)v_\pi (s)vπ​(s)﻿, thus it’s just a theoretical proxy. We shall use some estimated v^π\hat{v}_{\pi}v^π​﻿ (built from Monte-Carlo returns, TD targets, etc. ) in practice.

Stochastic-gradient/Semi-gradient Methods

1. Setting

  • We want to approximate vπ(s)v_\pi(s)vπ​(s)﻿ using v^(s,w)\hat v(s,\mathbf{w})v^(s,w)﻿, where w\mathbf{w}w﻿ is a vector of parameters (weights).
  • v^\hat vv^﻿ is differentiable w.r.t. w\mathbf{w}w﻿.
  • At each time step ttt﻿, we have a current parameter vector wt\mathbf{w}_twt​﻿.

2. Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) update

What happens at each update>>

They imagine:

  • You get an example (St,vπ(St))(S_t, v_\pi(S_t))(St​,vπ​(St​))﻿.

    That is, the input is a state StS_tSt​﻿, and the target output is its true value vπ(St)v_\pi(S_t)vπ​(St​)﻿.

  • Of course, in practice we don’t know vπ(St)v_\pi(S_t)vπ​(St​)﻿, but for now assume we magically do (this is just to explain the math).

Then the error on that example is: [vπ(St)−v^(St,wt)]2.\big[v_\pi(S_t) - \hat v(S_t, \mathbf{w}_t)\big]^2.[vπ​(St​)−v^(St​,wt​)]2.﻿

In supervised learning, to reduce squared error, you adjust weights by moving in the direction of the negative gradient of the loss.

So they write:

wt+1≐wt−12α∇(vπ(St)−v^(St,wt))2\mathbf{w}_{t+1} \doteq \mathbf{w}_t - \tfrac{1}{2}\alpha \nabla \Big( v_\pi(S_t) - \hat v(S_t,\mathbf{w}_t)\Big)^2wt+1​≐wt​−21​α∇(vπ​(St​)−v^(St​,wt​))2﻿

Simplify (chain rule):

wt+1=wt+α[vπ(St)−v^(St,wt)]∇v^(St,wt).\mathbf{w}_{t+1} = \mathbf{w}_t + \alpha \big[v_\pi(S_t) - \hat v(S_t,\mathbf{w}_t)\big] \nabla \hat v(S_t,\mathbf{w}_t).wt+1​=wt​+α[vπ​(St​)−v^(St​,wt​)]∇v^(St​,wt​).﻿

(PS: the gradient is computed by ∇f(w)≐(∂f∂w1,∂f∂w2,…,∂f∂wd)⊤.\nabla f(\mathbf{w}) \doteq \left(\frac{\partial f}{\partial w_1}, \frac{\partial f}{\partial w_2}, \dots, \frac{\partial f}{\partial w_d}\right)^\top.∇f(w)≐(∂w1​∂f​,∂w2​∂f​,…,∂wd​∂f​)⊤.﻿)

“Stochastic”: It uses only one sample at a time.

  • In RL, we don’t know the true value vπ(St)v_\pi(S_t)vπ​(St​)﻿. Instead, we replace it with a target UtU_tUt​﻿:
    • Could be Monte Carlo return,
    • or TD bootstrapped target.

⇒ That’s where the semi-gradient methods come in: we pretend UtU_tUt​﻿ is the true value and update toward it.

So the real update would be:

wt+1=wt+α[Ut−v^(St,wt)]∇v^(St,wt).\mathbf{w}_{t+1} = \mathbf{w}_t + \alpha \big[U_t - \hat v(S_t,\mathbf{w}_t)\big] \nabla \hat v(S_t,\mathbf{w}_t).wt+1​=wt​+α[Ut​−v^(St​,wt​)]∇v^(St​,wt​).﻿

When does it converge?

  • If UtU_tUt​﻿ is an unbiased estimate of vπ(St)v_\pi(S_t)vπ​(St​)﻿ (e.g. Ut=GtU_t = G_tUt​=Gt​﻿, the full return), then this update converges to a local optimum of VE(w)VE(\mathbf{w})VE(w)﻿.

(That’s why Monte Carlo works — GtG_tGt​﻿ is an unbiased sample of the true value.)

Gradient Monte Carlo

Unbiased UtU_tUt​﻿:

Semi-gradient TD(0)

Use the TD update as target. The target is biased (not independent of wt\mathbf{w}_twt​﻿).

  • You update the weights using the gradient w.r.t. the current prediction v^(St,w)\hat v(S_t,\mathbf{w})v^(St​,w)﻿.
  • But you ignore the fact that the target also depends on w\mathbf{w}w﻿.

Linear Methods

We represent the value function as: v^(s,w)=w⊤x(s),\hat v(s, \mathbf{w}) = \mathbf{w}^\top \mathbf{x}(s),v^(s,w)=w⊤x(s),﻿

where:

  • w=(w1,w2,…,wd)⊤\mathbf{w} = (w_1, w_2, \dots, w_d)^\topw=(w1​,w2​,…,wd​)⊤﻿ = parameter vector.
  • x(s)=(x1(s),x2(s),…,xd(s))⊤\mathbf{x}(s) = (x_1(s), x_2(s), \dots, x_d(s))^\topx(s)=(x1​(s),x2​(s),…,xd​(s))⊤﻿ = feature vector of state sss﻿.
  • Each xi(s)x_i(s)xi​(s)﻿ is a feature (or basis function) describing some property of the state.

So v^(s,w)\hat v(s,w)v^(s,w)﻿ is linear in the weights, even if the features themselves are nonlinear functions of the state.

Advantages:

If features are well-chosen, linear methods are very powerful (basis functions, Fourier features, tile coding, etc.).

Unlike nonlinear methods, linear approximators generally have one global optimum (convex loss).

This means:

  • Gradient Monte Carlo with linear function approximation converges to the best possible linear approximation of vπv_\pivπ​﻿.
  • TD methods with linear approximation are also provably convergent in many cases.

Gradient for linear methods

Because: v^(s,w)=∑i=1dwixi(s),\hat v(s, \mathbf{w}) = \sum_{i=1}^d w_i x_i(s),v^(s,w)=∑i=1d​wi​xi​(s),﻿ the gradient w.r.t. w\mathbf{w}w﻿ is simply: ∇v^(s,w)=x(s).\nabla \hat v(s,\mathbf{w}) = \mathbf{x}(s).∇v^(s,w)=x(s).﻿ This makes updates especially simple.

General SGD update

Plugging into the SGD rule: wt+1=wt+α[Ut−v^(St,wt)]x(St).\mathbf{w}_{t+1} = \mathbf{w}_t + \alpha \big[ U_t - \hat v(S_t,\mathbf{w}_t)\big] \mathbf{x}(S_t).wt+1​=wt​+α[Ut​−v^(St​,wt​)]x(St​).﻿

So we just shift w\mathbf{w}w﻿ in the direction of the feature vector, scaled by the error.

Semi-gradient TD(0) update

Bellman equation says vπ(St)v_\pi(S_t)vπ​(St​)﻿ is the expectation of Rt+1+γvπ(St+1)R_{t+1} + \gamma v_\pi(S_{t+1})Rt+1​+γvπ​(St+1​)﻿.

For linear case, plugging v^(s,w)=w⊤x(s)\hat v(s,w) = w^\top x(s)v^(s,w)=w⊤x(s)﻿ and Ut=Rt+1+v^(St+1,w)U_t = R_{t+1} + \hat v(S_{t+1}, w)Ut​=Rt+1​+v^(St+1​,w)﻿ into the general update gives:

wt+1=wt+α(Rt+1+γwt⊤xt+1−wt⊤xt)xt,\mathbf{w}_{t+1} = \mathbf{w}_t + \alpha \Big( R_{t+1} + \gamma \mathbf{w}_t^\top \mathbf{x}_{t+1} - \mathbf{w}_t^\top \mathbf{x}_t \Big)\mathbf{x}_t,wt+1​=wt​+α(Rt+1​+γwt⊤​xt+1​−wt⊤​xt​)xt​,﻿ where xt=x(St)\mathbf{x}_t = \mathbf{x}(S_t)xt​=x(St​)﻿.

This is just TD error δt\delta_tδt​﻿ times the feature vector:

δt=Rt+1+γwt⊤xt+1−wt⊤xt.\delta_t = R_{t+1} + \gamma \mathbf{w}_t^\top \mathbf{x}_{t+1} - \mathbf{w}_t^\top \mathbf{x}_t.δt​=Rt+1​+γwt⊤​xt+1​−wt⊤​xt​.﻿

Convergence analysis

The raw TD(0) update is noisy. So to analyze convergence, we take the expectation of the update, conditioned on current weights wt\mathbf{w}_twt​﻿:

E[wt+1∣wt]=wt+α(b−Awt).\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{w}_{t+1} \mid \mathbf{w}_t] = \mathbf{w}_t + \alpha \big(\mathbf{b} - A\mathbf{w}_t\big).E[wt+1​∣wt​]=wt​+α(b−Awt​).﻿

where:

  • b=E[Rt+1xt]∈Rd\mathbf{b} = \mathbb{E}[R_{t+1}\mathbf{x}_t] \in \mathbb{R}^db=E[Rt+1​xt​]∈Rd﻿
  • A=E[xt(xt−γxt+1)⊤]∈Rd×dA = \mathbb{E}[\mathbf{x}_t(\mathbf{x}_t - \gamma \mathbf{x}_{t+1})^\top] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}A=E[xt​(xt​−γxt+1​)⊤]∈Rd×d﻿

If the algorithm converges (then E[wt+1−wt∣wt]=0\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{w}_{t+1} - \mathbf{w}_t \mid \mathbf{w}_t] = 0E[wt+1​−wt​∣wt​]=0﻿, E[wt+1∣wt]=wt\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{w}_{t+1} \mid \mathbf{w}_t] = \mathbf{w}_tE[wt+1​∣wt​]=wt​﻿), the expected change must be zero:

b−AwTD=0\mathbf{b} - A \mathbf{w}_{TD} = 0b−AwTD​=0﻿  ⟹  wTD=A−1b.\implies \mathbf{w}_{TD} = A^{-1}\mathbf{b}.⟹wTD​=A−1b.﻿

This wTD\mathbf{w}_{TD}wTD​﻿ is called the TD fixed point.

The semi-gradient TD(0) converges to the TD fixed points. Detailed proof see p. 206 in the book.

n-step semi-gradient TD

for estimating v^≈vπ\hat v\approx v_\piv^≈vπ​﻿

This is just the n-step extension of semi-gradient TD(0).

  • In TD(0), the target is one-step bootstrapped:

    Ut=Rt+1+γv^(St+1,wt).U_t = R_{t+1} + \gamma \hat v(S_{t+1}, \mathbf{w}_t).Ut​=Rt+1​+γv^(St+1​,wt​).﻿

  • In n-step TD, the target includes the first n rewards’, then bootstraps at step n:

    Gt:t+n=Rt+1+γRt+2+⋯+γn−1Rt+n+γnv^(St+n,wt).G_{t:t+n} = R_{t+1} + \gamma R_{t+2} + \cdots + \gamma^{n-1} R_{t+n} + \gamma^n \hat v(S_{t+n}, \mathbf{w}_t).Gt:t+n​=Rt+1​+γRt+2​+⋯+γn−1Rt+n​+γnv^(St+n​,wt​).﻿

Feature construction for linear methods

Why features matter:

  • Linear function approximation has nice convergence guarantees. But it can only be as good as the features you choose.
  • Features should capture the aspects of the state space that are important for predicting value.

E.g.,

  • If valuing geometric objects, features could represent shape, size, color, etc.
  • If valuing robot states, features could include position, velocity, battery level, sensor readings, etc.

But using purely linear feature has the same drawbacks as in traditional ML: It cannot capture interactions between different variables. Thus we also consider:

Polynomials

(Might have Runge phenomenon at the edge.)

For a state s=(s1,s2,...,sk)s = (s_1, s_2, ..., s_k)s=(s1​,s2​,...,sk​)﻿, define polynomial features as: xi(s)=∏j=1ksjci,j,x_i(s) = \prod_{j=1}^k s_j^{c_{i,j}},xi​(s)=∏j=1k​sjci,j​​,﻿

  • Each exponent ci,jc_{i,j}ci,j​﻿ is chosen from {0,1,…,n}\{0, 1, \dots, n\}{0,1,…,n}﻿.

These features make up the order-n polynomial basis for dimension k, which contains (n+1)k(n+1)^k(n+1)k﻿ different features. ← (ci,j∈{0,1,...n})#features(c_{i, j}\in \{0, 1, ...n\})^\textrm{\#features}(ci,j​∈{0,1,...n})#features﻿

Fourier Basis

Any (nice) function can be expressed as a sum of sine and cosine functions of different frequencies.

One-dimensional Fourier basis:

Suppose the state is a single number s∈[0,1]s \in [0,1]s∈[0,1]﻿.

The Fourier features are:

xi(s)=cos⁡(iπs),i=0,1,2,…,n.x_i(s) = \cos(i \pi s), \quad i=0,1,2,\dots,n.xi​(s)=cos(iπs),i=0,1,2,…,n.﻿

So the feature vector could be:

x(s)=(1,cos⁡(πs),cos⁡(2πs),cos⁡(3πs),…,cos⁡(nπs)).\mathbf{x}(s) = (1, \cos(\pi s), \cos(2\pi s), \cos(3\pi s), \dots, \cos(n\pi s)).x(s)=(1,cos(πs),cos(2πs),cos(3πs),…,cos(nπs)).﻿

In practice, RL usually uses cosine features:

xi(s)=cos⁡(iπs),i=0,…,nx_i(s) = \cos(i\pi s), \quad i=0,\dots,nxi​(s)=cos(iπs),i=0,…,n﻿

(Any function can be symmetric if you set τ\tauτ﻿ to twice the length of the interval of interest and restrict attention to the approximation over the half interval [0, τ\tauτ﻿/2]. )

Multi-dimensional Fourier Cosine Basis

  • If state sss﻿ has kkk﻿ components: s=(s1,s2,…,sk)⊤∈[0,1]k,s = (s_1, s_2, \dots, s_k)^\top \in [0,1]^k,s=(s1​,s2​,…,sk​)⊤∈[0,1]k,﻿

    then each Fourier feature is

    xi(s)=cos⁡(π ci⊤s),x_i(s) = \cos(\pi \, c^{i\top} s),xi​(s)=cos(πci⊤s),﻿

    where ci=(c1i,c2i,…,cki)c^i = (c^i_1, c^i_2, \dots, c^i_k)ci=(c1i​,c2i​,…,cki​)﻿ with each cji∈{0,…,n}c^i_j \in \{0,\dots,n\}cji​∈{0,…,n}﻿.

  • This gives (n+1)k(n+1)^k(n+1)k﻿ possible features (all combinations of frequencies across dimensions).

Coarse Coding

“overlapping binary features”

  • Represent the state space with overlapping receptive fields (e.g., circles).
  • Each circle = one binary feature:
    • State inside circle → feature = 1.
    • State outside → feature = 0.
  • A state is represented by the set of circles it belongs to.

Learning effect:

  • Each circle has its own weight.
  • When training at state sss﻿, all overlapping circles get updated.
  • So nearby states (sharing circles with sss﻿) also get partially updated → generalization.
  • Small circles = local generalization.
  • Large circles = broad generalization.

The overlap is decided by the features designed by us.

Features with large receptive fields give broad generalization, but might also seem to limit the learned function to a coarse approximation, unable to make discriminations much finer than the width of the receptive fields. Happily, this is not the case. Initial generalization from one point to another is indeed controlled by the size and shape of the receptive fields, but acuity, the finest discrimination ultimately possible, is controlled more by the total number of features.

Tile Coding

Instead of designing the binary feature functions in classic coarse coding, we just bin the state space into tiles.

In tile coding the receptive fields of the features are grouped into partitions of the state space. Each such partition is called a tiling, and each element of the partition is called a tile. By definition the tiles of a partition do not overlap.

E.g.

The simplest tiling of a two-dimensional state space is a uniform grid such as that shown on the left side of Figure 9.9.

The shape of the tiles will determine the nature of generalization.

Hashing

In high dimensions, the number of possible tiles explodes and might cause memory blow-up. Hashing reduces memory by mapping many possible tiles into a smaller set of “buckets”, with each hash bucket representing multiple, non-contiguous regions of the state space.

  • Often, we only need high resolution in a small part of the space.
  • Hashing spreads out the representation, giving enough resolution where needed without storing all possible tiles.

Radial Basis Functions (RBFs)

In coarse coding, features are binary (0 or 1 depending on whether you’re inside a region). With RBFs, features are graded: xi(s)=exp⁡ ⁣(−∥s−ci∥22σi2)x_i(s) = \exp\!\left(-\frac{\|s - c_i\|^2}{2\sigma_i^2}\right)xi​(s)=exp(−2σi2​∥s−ci​∥2​)﻿

  • cic_ici​﻿ = center of the feature.
  • σi\sigma_iσi​﻿ = width (spread).
  • Value in [0,1][0,1][0,1]﻿, decreases smoothly with distance from the center.

It’s a natural extension of coarse computing with differentiable functions. But in practice, it is computationally expensive and doesn’t show significant improvement (also it is challenged by the curse of dimensionality).

Selecting Step-Size Parameters Manually

Most RL algorithms use stochastic gradient descent (SGD), convergence depends heavily on α\alphaα﻿.

Too large → unstable. Too small → learning is too slow.

  • Theory says: αt∼1/t\alpha_t \sim 1/tαt​∼1/t﻿ ensures convergence. But this decays too quickly, which causes learning slows down too much.
  • More advanced methods (like LSTD with optimal matrix step-sizes) exist, but they are computationally expensive (require O(d2)O(d^2)O(d2)﻿ parameters).

Practical intuition (from tabular case)

  • If α=1\alpha = 1α=1﻿: you fully replace the estimate with the latest sample (no averaging).
  • If α=110\alpha = \frac{1}{10}α=101​﻿: about 10 samples are needed for the estimate to stabilize.
  • If α=1100\alpha = \frac{1}{100}α=1001​﻿: about 100 samples.

General rule: α≈1τ\alpha \approx \frac{1}{\tau}α≈τ1​﻿ → the estimate averages about τ\tauτ﻿ recent experiences, with more weight on the latest ones.

Rule of thumb

For linear SGD/TD the update is w←w+α [U−v^(S;w)] x(S).\mathbf{w}\leftarrow \mathbf{w}+\alpha\,[U-\hat v(S;\mathbf{w})]\,\mathbf{x}(S).w←w+α[U−v^(S;w)]x(S).﻿

The immediate change in the prediction for the same state is

Δv^(S)  =  Δw⊤x  =  α [U−v^(S)]x⊤x⏟feature energy.\Delta \hat v(S) \;=\;\Delta\mathbf{w}^\top\mathbf{x}\;=\; \alpha\,[U-\hat v(S)]\underbrace{\mathbf{x}^\top\mathbf{x}}_{\text{feature energy}} .Δv^(S)=Δw⊤x=α[U−v^(S)]feature energyx⊤x​​.﻿

So the step toward the target is scaled by x⊤x\mathbf{x}^\top\mathbf{x}x⊤x﻿. If you want the estimate to behave like an average over roughly τ\tauτ﻿ visits (i.e., move about 1/τ1/\tau1/τ﻿ toward the target each time), choose α  ≈  1τ E[x⊤x]\alpha \;\approx\; \frac{1}{\tau\,\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{x}^\top\mathbf{x}]}α≈τE[x⊤x]1​﻿.

This works best when feature vectors have similar lengths (ideally x⊤x\mathbf{x}^\top\mathbf{x}x⊤x﻿ is constant).

Feature type

  • Tile coding (binary, sparse): if a state activates mmm tiles, then x⊤x=m\mathbf{x}^\top\mathbf{x}=mx⊤x=m﻿. Rule: α≈1/(τm)\alpha \approx 1/(\tau m)α≈1/(τm)﻿.
  • Other features: standardize/scale so x\mathbf{x}x﻿ norms don’t vary wildly, then use the same formula with E[x⊤x]\mathbb{E}[x^\top x]E[x⊤x]﻿.

Nonlinear Function Approximation: Artificial Neural Networks

ANN = NN in ML

Skipping some basic knowledge about DL . . .

Training the ANN in RL

The ANN’s weights θ\thetaθ﻿ are updated with gradient-based learning, using targets derived from RL algorithms.

  • Value function approximation (TD(0)):

    Loss:

    L(θ)=(Rt+1+γV(St+1;θ−)−V(St;θ))2L(\theta) = \left( R_{t+1} + \gamma V(S_{t+1}; \theta^-) - V(S_t; \theta) \right)^2L(θ)=(Rt+1​+γV(St+1​;θ−)−V(St​;θ))2﻿

    where θ−\theta^-θ−﻿ is a frozen/lagged copy for stability.

  • Q-learning with ANN (Deep Q-Network, DQN):

    Loss:

    L(θ)=(Rt+1+γmax⁡a′Q(St+1,a′;θ−)−Q(St,At;θ))2L(\theta) = \left( R_{t+1} + \gamma \max_{a'} Q(S_{t+1}, a'; \theta^-) - Q(S_t, A_t; \theta) \right)^2L(θ)=(Rt+1​+γmaxa′​Q(St+1​,a′;θ−)−Q(St​,At​;θ))2﻿

  • Policy gradient methods:

    Objective:

    J(θ)=Eπθ[∑tlog⁡πθ(At∣St)Gt]J(\theta) = \mathbb{E}_{\pi_\theta} \left[ \sum_t \log \pi_\theta(A_t|S_t) G_t \right]J(θ)=Eπθ​​[∑t​logπθ​(At​∣St​)Gt​]﻿

    and we maximize J(θ)J(\theta)J(θ)﻿ via gradient ascent.

i.e.,

Using the network itself to approximate the function (value function or action-value function), but update the target after each step (unlike the static supervised learning).

Although current reinforcement learning theory is mostly limited to methods using tabular or linear function approximation methods, the impressive performances of notable reinforcement learning applications owe much of their success to nonlinear function approximation by multi-layer ANNs.

Least-Squares TD

We recall the TD fixed point:

The raw TD(0) update is noisy. So to analyze convergence, we take the expectation of the update, conditioned on current weights wt\mathbf{w}_twt​﻿:

E[wt+1∣wt]=wt+α(b−Awt).\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{w}_{t+1} \mid \mathbf{w}_t] = \mathbf{w}_t + \alpha \big(\mathbf{b} - A\mathbf{w}_t\big).E[wt+1​∣wt​]=wt​+α(b−Awt​).﻿

where:

  • b=E[Rt+1xt]∈Rd\mathbf{b} = \mathbb{E}[R_{t+1}\mathbf{x}_t] \in \mathbb{R}^db=E[Rt+1​xt​]∈Rd﻿
  • A=E[xt(xt−γxt+1)⊤]∈Rd×dA = \mathbb{E}[\mathbf{x}_t(\mathbf{x}_t - \gamma \mathbf{x}_{t+1})^\top] \in \mathbb{R}^{d \times d}A=E[xt​(xt​−γxt+1​)⊤]∈Rd×d﻿

If the algorithm converges (then E[wt+1−wt∣wt]=0\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{w}_{t+1} - \mathbf{w}_t \mid \mathbf{w}_t] = 0E[wt+1​−wt​∣wt​]=0﻿, E[wt+1∣wt]=wt\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{w}_{t+1} \mid \mathbf{w}_t] = \mathbf{w}_tE[wt+1​∣wt​]=wt​﻿), the expected change must be zero:

b−AwTD=0\mathbf{b} - A \mathbf{w}_{TD} = 0b−AwTD​=0﻿  ⟹  wTD=A−1b.\implies \mathbf{w}_{TD} = A^{-1}\mathbf{b}.⟹wTD​=A−1b.﻿

This wTD\mathbf{w}_{TD}wTD​﻿ is called the TD fixed point.

Instead of using iterative TD update, we can just use least square to solve the linear system in one shot. ⇒ Least-square TD (LSTD).

The sample estimates are:

A^t=∑k=0t−1xk(xk−γxk+1)⊤+ϵI,\hat{\mathbf{A}}_t = \sum_{k=0}^{t-1} \mathbf{x}_k(\mathbf{x}_k - \gamma \mathbf{x}_{k+1})^\top + \epsilon \mathbf{I},A^t​=∑k=0t−1​xk​(xk​−γxk+1​)⊤+ϵI,﻿

b^t=∑k=0t−1Rk+1xk.\hat{\mathbf{b}}_t = \sum_{k=0}^{t-1} R_{k+1}\mathbf{x}_k.b^t​=∑k=0t−1​Rk+1​xk​.﻿

Then the solution is: w^t=A^t−1b^t.\hat{\mathbf{w}}_t = \hat{\mathbf{A}}_t^{-1} \hat{\mathbf{b}}_t.w^t​=A^t−1​b^t​.﻿

So instead of slowly adjusting w\mathbf{w}w﻿, we just solve a linear system. (The ϵI\epsilon \mathbf{I}ϵI﻿ ensures A^t\hat{\mathbf{A}}_tA^t​﻿ is invertible.)

But solving least-square is computationally expensive:

  • Semi-gradient TD(0):
    • Cost per update: O(d)O(d)O(d)﻿ (just a vector update).
    • Memory: O(d)O(d)O(d)﻿.
  • Naive LSTD:
    • You must update A^t\hat{\mathbf{A}}_tA^t​﻿, a d×dd \times dd×d﻿ matrix → O(d2)O(d^2)O(d2)﻿.
    • Then invert it at the end → O(d3)O(d^3)O(d3)﻿.
    • Memory: O(d2)O(d^2)O(d2)﻿.

Sherman–Morrison trick

Instead of recomputing the inverse A^t−1\hat{\mathbf{A}}_t^{-1}A^t−1​﻿ from scratch, you can update it incrementally:

A^t−1=A^t−1−1−A^t−1−1xt(xt−γxt+1)⊤A^t−1−11+(xt−γxt+1)⊤A^t−1−1xt.\hat{\mathbf{A}}_t^{-1} = \hat{\mathbf{A}}_{t-1}^{-1} - \frac{\hat{\mathbf{A}}_{t-1}^{-1} \mathbf{x}_t (\mathbf{x}_t - \gamma \mathbf{x}_{t+1})^\top \hat{\mathbf{A}}_{t-1}^{-1}} {1 + (\mathbf{x}_t - \gamma \mathbf{x}_{t+1})^\top \hat{\mathbf{A}}_{t-1}^{-1} \mathbf{x}_t}.A^t−1​=A^t−1−1​−1+(xt​−γxt+1​)⊤A^t−1−1​xt​A^t−1−1​xt​(xt​−γxt+1​)⊤A^t−1−1​​.﻿

This is the Sherman–Morrison formula.

  • Each update only costs O(d2)O(d^2)O(d2)﻿ (matrix–vector multiplications).
  • Memory: still O(d2)O(d^2)O(d2)﻿.
  • Much better than recomputing a full inverse (O(d3)O(d^3)O(d3)﻿).

Thus the whole algorithm becomes practical for moderate ddd﻿.

Nonparametric Methods

Memory-based methods

Memory-based methods don’t learn parameters. They just store past experiences (state, return estimates) and use them directly at query time.

When you want to estimate v(s)v(s)v(s)﻿:

  1. Retrieve examples from memory whose states are close to sss﻿.
  1. Use them to build a local estimate.

Common approaches:

  • Nearest neighbor: return the value of the closest stored state.
  • Weighted average: take a weighted average of nearby states’ values, with weights decreasing by distance.
  • Locally weighted regression: fit a small local parametric model (like a weighted least squares) around the query state.

Kernel-based methods

A memory-based function with a kernel function

Kernel regression is the memory-based method that computes a kernel weighted average of the targets of all examples stored in memory, assigning the result to the query state.

  • Kernel-based methods formalize this with a kernel function k(s,s′)k(s, s')k(s,s′)﻿, which assigns a weight to each stored example s′s's′﻿ when estimating the value at query state sss﻿.

So the estimate is: v^(s;D)=∑s′∈Dk(s,s′)g(s′),\hat{v}(s; \mathcal{D}) = \sum_{s' \in \mathcal{D}} k(s, s') g(s'),v^(s;D)=∑s′∈D​k(s,s′)g(s′),﻿ where g(s′)g(s')g(s′)﻿ is the stored target (like return estimate) for state s′s's′﻿.

Workflow:

  • The kernel k(s,s′)k(s, s')k(s,s′)﻿ measures similarity between sss﻿ and s′s's′﻿.
  • Examples:
    • Gaussian RBF kernel:

      k(s,s′)=exp⁡ ⁣(−∥s−s′∥22σ2).k(s, s') = \exp\!\left(-\frac{\|s-s'\|^2}{2\sigma^2}\right).k(s,s′)=exp(−2σ2∥s−s′∥2​).﻿

      States closer in Euclidean distance have higher influence.

    • Dot-product kernel:

      k(s,s′)=x(s)⊤x(s′),k(s, s') = x(s)^\top x(s'),k(s,s′)=x(s)⊤x(s′),﻿

      where x(s)x(s)x(s)﻿ is a feature representation.

So kernel regression is basically a weighted average of past examples, where the weights come from the kernel.

Disadvantages

  • Nonparametric → must store many past examples, memory heavy.
  • Computing v^(s)\hat{v}(s)v^(s)﻿ requires summing over many stored points, so query time is expensive.
  • In high dimensions, kernel methods suffer from the “curse of dimensionality” (similarity becomes less meaningful).

Chapter 10 - On-policy Control with Approximation

Episodic Semi-gradient Control

1. Semi-gradient prediction (with action-values)

We recall the general update (Equation 10.1) is

wt+1=wt+α[Ut−q^(St,At,wt)]∇q^(St,At,wt).\mathbf{w}_{t+1} = \mathbf{w}_t + \alpha \big[ U_t - \hat q(S_t, A_t, \mathbf{w}_t) \big] \nabla \hat q(S_t, A_t, \mathbf{w}_t).wt+1​=wt​+α[Ut​−q^​(St​,At​,wt​)]∇q^​(St​,At​,wt​).﻿

  • Here UtU_tUt​﻿ is some target (MC return, n-step return, TD target, etc.).
  • This is just learning to approximate the value of a fixed policy.
  • Example: one-step SARSA prediction under a fixed policy:

    wt+1=wt+α[Rt+1+γq^(St+1,At+1,wt)−q^(St,At,wt)]∇q^(St,At,wt).\mathbf{w}_{t+1} = \mathbf{w}_t + \alpha \big[ R_{t+1} + \gamma \hat q(S_{t+1}, A_{t+1}, \mathbf{w}_t) - \hat q(S_t, A_t, \mathbf{w}_t) \big] \nabla \hat q(S_t, A_t, \mathbf{w}_t).wt+1​=wt​+α[Rt+1​+γq^​(St+1​,At+1​,wt​)−q^​(St​,At​,wt​)]∇q^​(St​,At​,wt​).﻿

    This is called episodic semi-gradient one-step SARSA.

prediction = policy is fixed.

2. Semi-gradient control

To form control methods, we need to couple such action-value prediction methods with techniques for policy improvement and action selection. Suitable techniques applicable to continuous actions, or to actions from large discrete sets, are a topic of ongoing research with as yet no clear resolution.
  • That means: instead of just evaluating a fixed policy, we improve it iteratively.
  • We use the same prediction update as above, but add policy improvement:
    • E.g., make the behavior policy ϵ\epsilonϵ﻿-greedy with respect to the current estimate q^(S,a,w)\hat q(S,a,\mathbf{w})q^​(S,a,w)﻿.
    • This couples evaluation (prediction) with improvement (control).

So:

  • Prediction: update w\mathbf{w}w﻿ while following a fixed policy.
  • Control: update w\mathbf{w}w﻿ while also improving the policy (via greedy/ε-greedy wrt q^\hat qq^​﻿).

The semi-gradient Sarsa is just like the tabular Sarsa we discussed in the previous chapters.

For n-step it’s similar:

Average Reward

Instead of discounting, define the differential return:

Gt=Rt+1−r(π)  +  Rt+2−r(π)  +  Rt+3−r(π)+⋯G_t = R_{t+1} - r(\pi) \;+\; R_{t+2} - r(\pi) \;+\; R_{t+3} - r(\pi) + \cdotsGt​=Rt+1​−r(π)+Rt+2​−r(π)+Rt+3​−r(π)+⋯﻿

Here r(π)r(\pi)r(π)﻿ is the average reward per time step under policy π\piπ﻿.

They look the same as before, but with adjusted rewards:

  • State value:

    vπ(s)=Eπ[Gt∣St=s]v_\pi(s) = \mathbb{E}_\pi \big[ G_t \mid S_t = s \big]vπ​(s)=Eπ​[Gt​∣St​=s]﻿

  • Action value:

    qπ(s,a)=Eπ[Gt∣St=s,At=a]q_\pi(s,a) = \mathbb{E}_\pi \big[ G_t \mid S_t = s, A_t=a \big]qπ​(s,a)=Eπ​[Gt​∣St​=s,At​=a]﻿

And the Bellman equations become:

vπ(s)=∑aπ(a∣s)∑s′,rp(s′,r∣s,a)[r−r(π)+vπ(s′)]v_\pi(s) = \sum_a \pi(a|s) \sum_{s',r} p(s',r|s,a) \Big[r - r(\pi) + v_\pi(s')\Big]vπ​(s)=∑a​π(a∣s)∑s′,r​p(s′,r∣s,a)[r−r(π)+vπ​(s′)]﻿

TD errors in average-reward setting:

  • Value-based:

    δt=Rt+1−Rˉt+v^(St+1,wt)−v^(St,wt)\delta_t = R_{t+1} - \bar{R}_t + \hat v(S_{t+1},w_t) - \hat v(S_t,w_t)δt​=Rt+1​−Rˉt​+v^(St+1​,wt​)−v^(St​,wt​)﻿

  • Action-value-based:

    δt=Rt+1−Rˉt+q^(St+1,At+1,wt)−q^(St,At,wt)\delta_t = R_{t+1} - \bar{R}_t + \hat q(S_{t+1},A_{t+1},w_t) - \hat q(S_t,A_t,w_t)δt​=Rt+1​−Rˉt​+q^​(St+1​,At+1​,wt​)−q^​(St​,At​,wt​)﻿

Here Rˉt\bar{R}_tRˉt​﻿ is the current estimate of the average reward.

Update rule:

For semi-gradient Sarsa,

wt+1=wt+α δt ∇q^(St,At,wt)w_{t+1} = w_t + \alpha \, \delta_t \, \nabla \hat q(S_t,A_t,w_t)wt+1​=wt​+αδt​∇q^​(St​,At​,wt​)﻿

Exactly the same as before, but with the differential TD error.

Chapter 13 - Policy Gradient Methods

Now we move to policy-gradient methods, where:

  • We don’t pick actions by consulting a value function.
  • Instead, we directly learn a parameterized policy — basically a neural network (or any differentiable function) that outputs a probability distribution over actions.

Formally:

π(a∣s,θ)=Pr⁡[At=a∣St=s,θt=θ]\pi(a|s, \theta) = \Pr[A_t = a \mid S_t = s, \theta_t = \theta]π(a∣s,θ)=Pr[At​=a∣St​=s,θt​=θ]﻿

means:

“Given state sss﻿ and current parameters θ\thetaθ﻿, what’s the probability that the policy picks action aaa﻿?”

So instead of learning a table of Q-values, we learn the parameters θ\thetaθ﻿ of this probability model.

How learning works here

We want to find parameters θ that make performance J(θ) as large as possible, where J(θ)J(θ)J(θ)﻿ is some measure of expected return (like average reward or total episode return).

So we use gradient ascent on J(θ)J(θ)J(θ)﻿:

θt+1=θt+α ∇J(θt)^\theta_{t+1} = \theta_t + \alpha \, \widehat{\nabla {J(\theta_t)}}θt+1​=θt​+α∇J(θt​)​﻿

Here:

  • α\alphaα﻿: learning rate
  • ∇J(θt)^\widehat{\nabla {J(\theta_t)}}∇J(θt​)​﻿: an estimate of the gradient (because we don’t know the true gradient — we sample it from experience)

This is why it’s called a policy-gradient method — we literally ascend the gradient of expected performance with respect to the policy parameters.

Actor–Critic: when we also use value functions

Sometimes we still want a value function to help reduce variance or provide better updates.

If we have both:

  • Actor: the parameterized policy π(a∣s,θ)\pi(a|s, \theta)π(a∣s,θ)﻿
  • Critic: an estimated value function v(s,w)v(s, w)v(s,w)﻿ or Q(s,a,w)Q(s,a,w)Q(s,a,w)﻿

then the method is called an actor-critic algorithm.

The critic helps the actor learn faster and more stably by estimating how good each state or action is.

Policy Approximation

Policy Parameterization (Discrete Actions)

(a) General differentiable form

π(a∣s,θ)>0,∑aπ(a∣s,θ)=1,∇θπ(a∣s,θ) exists.\pi(a|s,\theta) > 0,\quad \sum_a \pi(a|s,\theta) = 1,\quad \nabla_\theta \pi(a|s,\theta) \text{ exists.}π(a∣s,θ)>0,∑a​π(a∣s,θ)=1,∇θ​π(a∣s,θ) exists.﻿

(b) Soft-max in action preferences

Define preferences h(s,a,θ)h(s,a,\theta)h(s,a,θ)﻿ (unnormalized scores).

π(a∣s,θ)=eh(s,a,θ)∑beh(s,b,θ).\pi(a|s,\theta) = \frac{e^{h(s,a,\theta)}}{\sum_b e^{h(s,b,\theta)}}.π(a∣s,θ)=∑b​eh(s,b,θ)eh(s,a,θ)​.﻿

Optional temperature version:

π(a∣s,θ,T)=eh(s,a,θ)/T∑beh(s,b,θ)/T,\pi(a|s,\theta,T) = \frac{e^{h(s,a,\theta)/T}}{\sum_b e^{h(s,b,\theta)/T}},π(a∣s,θ,T)=∑b​eh(s,b,θ)/Teh(s,a,θ)/T​,﻿

with T↓0T \downarrow 0T↓0﻿ making the policy more deterministic.

Common forms of h(s,a,θ)h(s,a,\theta)h(s,a,θ)﻿:

  1. Linear features: h(s,a,θ)=θ⊤x(s,a),h(s,a,\theta) = \theta^\top x(s,a),h(s,a,θ)=θ⊤x(s,a),﻿
  1. Neural network output: h=fθ(s,a)h = f_\theta(s,a)h=fθ​(s,a)﻿

Remarks:

  • Policy-gradient methods optimize parameters of the policy directly, not via Q-values.
  • Soft-max parameterization ensures smooth, differentiable, and flexible behavior.

2. The policy gradient theorem

We want to maximize expected performance J(θ)=Eπθ[Gt],J(\theta) = \mathbb{E}_{\pi_\theta}[G_t],J(θ)=Eπθ​​[Gt​],﻿ where GtG_tGt​﻿ is the return (sum of future rewards) when following policy πθ(a∣s)\pi_\theta(a|s)πθ​(a∣s)﻿.

We need the gradient: ∇θJ(θ)\nabla_\theta J(\theta)∇θ​J(θ)﻿ so that we can do gradient ascent.

The expectation Eπθ\mathbb{E}_{\pi_\theta}Eπθ​​﻿ depends on the probabilities of all trajectories under the policy — so J(θ)J(\theta)J(θ)﻿ depends on πθ\pi_\thetaπθ​﻿ in a complex way.

The policy gradient theorem gives the exact formula for how to change a policy’s parameters θ\thetaθ﻿ to increase expected reward. It tells us which direction to move θ so that actions leading to higher long-term returns become more likely.

It can be shown that (p. 325): Up to a positive scaling constant,

∇J(θ)∝∑sμ(s)∑a∇π(a∣s)qπ(s,a).\nabla J(\theta) \propto \sum_s \mu(s) \sum_a \nabla \pi(a|s) q_\pi(s,a).∇J(θ)∝∑s​μ(s)∑a​∇π(a∣s)qπ​(s,a).﻿

Because ∇π(a∣s)=π(a∣s)∇log⁡π(a∣s)\nabla \pi(a|s) = \pi(a|s) \nabla \log \pi(a|s)∇π(a∣s)=π(a∣s)∇logπ(a∣s)﻿, we can rewrite it as an expectation:

∇J(θ)=Es∼μ,a∼π[∇θlog⁡π(a∣s,θ) qπ(s,a)].\nabla J(\theta) = \mathbb{E}_{s \sim \mu, a \sim \pi} \big[ \nabla_\theta \log \pi(a|s,\theta)\, q_\pi(s,a) \big].∇J(θ)=Es∼μ,a∼π​[∇θ​logπ(a∣s,θ)qπ​(s,a)].﻿

This works for any stochastic differentiable policy, including continuous actions.

3. REINFORCE - Monte-Carlo Policy Gradient

REINFORCE is the first practical policy-gradient algorithm, built directly from the policy gradient theorem.

It uses sampled returns GtG_tGt​﻿ from full episodes to estimate the gradient.

Start with

∇θJ(θ)∝∑sμ(s)∑aqπ(s,a)∇θπ(a∣s,θ)=Eπ ⁣[∑aqπ(St,a)∇θπ(a∣St,θ)].\nabla_\theta J(\theta) \propto \sum_s \mu(s) \sum_a q_\pi(s,a) \nabla_\theta \pi(a|s,\theta) = \mathbb{E}_\pi \!\Big[ \sum_a q_\pi(S_t,a)\nabla_\theta \pi(a|S_t,\theta) \Big].∇θ​J(θ)∝∑s​μ(s)∑a​qπ​(s,a)∇θ​π(a∣s,θ)=Eπ​[∑a​qπ​(St​,a)∇θ​π(a∣St​,θ)].﻿

To avoid summing over all actions, we sample one At∼π(⋅∣St)A_t \sim \pi(\cdot|S_t)At​∼π(⋅∣St​)﻿ and rewrite:

∇θJ(θ)=Eπ ⁣[qπ(St,At) ∇θπ(At∣St,θ)π(At∣St,θ)].\nabla_\theta J(\theta) = \mathbb{E}_\pi \!\Big[ q_\pi(S_t,A_t)\, \frac{\nabla_\theta \pi(A_t|S_t,\theta)}{\pi(A_t|S_t,\theta)} \Big].∇θ​J(θ)=Eπ​[qπ​(St​,At​)π(At​∣St​,θ)∇θ​π(At​∣St​,θ)​].﻿

Since qπ(St,At)=Eπ[Gt∣St,At]q_\pi(S_t,A_t) = \mathbb{E}_\pi[G_t|S_t,A_t]qπ​(St​,At​)=Eπ​[Gt​∣St​,At​]﻿, we get

∇θJ(θ)=Eπ ⁣[Gt ∇θln⁡πθ(At∣St)].\nabla_\theta J(\theta) = \mathbb{E}_\pi \!\Big[ G_t\, \nabla_\theta \ln \pi_\theta(A_t|S_t) \Big].∇θ​J(θ)=Eπ​[Gt​∇θ​lnπθ​(At​∣St​)].﻿

If f(θ)=πθ(a∣s)f(\theta) = \pi_\theta(a|s)f(θ)=πθ​(a∣s)﻿, then: ∇θlog⁡πθ(a∣s)=1πθ(a∣s)∇θπθ(a∣s).\nabla_\theta \log \pi_\theta(a|s) = \frac{1}{\pi_\theta(a|s)} \nabla_\theta \pi_\theta(a|s).∇θ​logπθ​(a∣s)=πθ​(a∣s)1​∇θ​πθ​(a∣s).﻿ Using stochastic gradient ascent, the update rule is:

θt+1=θt+α Gt ∇θln⁡πθ(At∣St)\theta_{t+1} = \theta_t + \alpha\, G_t\, \nabla_\theta \ln \pi_\theta(A_t|S_t)θt+1​=θt​+αGt​∇θ​lnπθ​(At​∣St​)﻿.

REINFORCE with Baseline

Policy Gradient with Baseline

∇θJ(θ)∝∑sμ(s)∑a[qπ(s,a)−b(s)] ∇θπ(a∣s,θ).\nabla_\theta J(\theta) \propto \sum_s \mu(s) \sum_a [q_\pi(s,a) - b(s)] \, \nabla_\theta \pi(a|s,\theta).∇θ​J(θ)∝∑s​μ(s)∑a​[qπ​(s,a)−b(s)]∇θ​π(a∣s,θ).﻿

  • The baseline can be any function of the state, as long as it does not depend on the action aaa﻿.
  • This works because:

    ∑ab(s)∇θπ(a∣s,θ)=b(s)∇θ∑aπ(a∣s,θ)=b(s)∇θ1=0.\sum_a b(s)\nabla_\theta \pi(a|s,\theta) = b(s)\nabla_\theta \sum_a \pi(a|s,\theta) = b(s)\nabla_\theta 1 = 0.∑a​b(s)∇θ​π(a∣s,θ)=b(s)∇θ​∑a​π(a∣s,θ)=b(s)∇θ​1=0.﻿

    So the expected gradient is unchanged — only its variance is reduced.

REINFORCE update with baseline

θt+1=θt+α (Gt−b(St)) ∇θlog⁡πθ(At∣St)\theta_{t+1} = \theta_t + \alpha\, (G_t - b(S_t))\, \nabla_\theta \log \pi_\theta(A_t|S_t)θt+1​=θt​+α(Gt​−b(St​))∇θ​logπθ​(At​∣St​)﻿

  • (Gt−b(St))(G_t - b(S_t))(Gt​−b(St​))﻿: advantage-like term, how much better or worse the return was than expected.
  • If Gt>b(St)G_t > b(S_t)Gt​>b(St​)﻿ → increase action probability;

    if Gt<b(St)G_t < b(S_t)Gt​<b(St​)﻿ → decrease it.

Choosing a baseline

A common and effective choice: b(St)=v^(St,w),b(S_t) = \hat{v}(S_t, \mathbf{w}),b(St​)=v^(St​,w),﻿

where v^\hat{v}v^﻿ is a learned state-value function with parameters w\mathbf{w}w﻿.

That turns REINFORCE into an actor–critic structure:

  • Actor: updates θ\thetaθ﻿ via the policy gradient.
  • Critic: learns v^(St,w)\hat{v}(S_t,\mathbf{w})v^(St​,w)﻿ to serve as the baseline.

Actor-Critic Methods

Motivation

  • REINFORCE with baseline uses a value estimate v^(s,w)\hat{v}(s,\mathbf{w})v^(s,w)﻿ only as a baseline — not for bootstrapping.
  • This keeps it unbiased but high-variance and slow, since updates happen only after full episodes (Monte Carlo).
  • Actor–critic fixes this by using bootstrapping — updating the value estimate from the next state’s estimated value rather than waiting for the full return.

Main idea

Actor–critic combines:

  • Actor: the policy πθ(a∣s)\pi_\theta(a|s)πθ​(a∣s)﻿ — decides which actions to take.
  • Critic: the state-value function v^(s,w)\hat{v}(s,\mathbf{w})v^(s,w)﻿ — evaluates how good the current state is.

The critic provides a bootstrapped target for the actor, enabling online and incremental updates.

Update rule

Start from REINFORCE with baseline:

θt+1=θt+α(Gt−v^(St,w))∇θlog⁡πθ(At∣St)\theta_{t+1} = \theta_t + \alpha (G_t - \hat{v}(S_t,\mathbf{w})) \nabla_\theta \log \pi_\theta(A_t|S_t)θt+1​=θt​+α(Gt​−v^(St​,w))∇θ​logπθ​(At​∣St​)﻿

Replace the full return GtG_tGt​﻿ by the one-step bootstrapped return:

Gt:t+1=Rt+1+γv^(St+1,w)G_{t:t+1} = R_{t+1} + \gamma \hat{v}(S_{t+1}, \mathbf{w})Gt:t+1​=Rt+1​+γv^(St+1​,w)﻿

to get:

θt+1=θt+α δt ∇θlog⁡πθ(At∣St)\theta_{t+1} = \theta_t + \alpha \, \delta_t \, \nabla_\theta \log \pi_\theta(A_t|S_t)θt+1​=θt​+αδt​∇θ​logπθ​(At​∣St​)﻿

where

δt=Rt+1+γv^(St+1,w)−v^(St,w)\delta_t = R_{t+1} + \gamma \hat{v}(S_{t+1},\mathbf{w}) - \hat{v}(S_t,\mathbf{w})δt​=Rt+1​+γv^(St+1​,w)−v^(St​,w)﻿

is the TD error.

pourtant, cependant = however

piège = trap

ainsi = Like this, in this way

rendre = faire, make

équilibre = balance

au début = at the beginning

Continuous Actions

Represent the policy as a probability density function over actions.

Common choice: Gaussian (Normal) policy

You model the policy as a normal distribution whose parameters depend on the state:

π(a∣s,θ)=1σ(s,θ)2πexp⁡ ⁣[−(a−μ(s,θ))22σ(s,θ)2].\pi(a|s,\theta) = \frac{1}{\sigma(s,\theta)\sqrt{2\pi}} \exp\!\Bigg[-\frac{(a - \mu(s,\theta))^2}{2\sigma(s,\theta)^2}\Bigg].π(a∣s,θ)=σ(s,θ)2π​1​exp[−2σ(s,θ)2(a−μ(s,θ))2​].﻿

Here:

  • a∈Ra \in \mathbb{R}a∈R﻿: continuous action
  • μ(s,θ)\mu(s,\theta)μ(s,θ)﻿: mean of the distribution (expected action)
  • σ(s,θ)>0\sigma(s,\theta) > 0σ(s,θ)>0﻿: standard deviation (controls exploration)

    Both are functions of the state, parameterized by neural networks or linear functions.

Update rule remains the same, just replace the discrete probability table with a continuous parametric distribution.

Actor-Critic: Variants

1. SAC — Soft Actor-Critic

Goal: maximize both expected reward and entropy:

J(π)=E[∑trt+αH(π(⋅∣st))],J(\pi) = \mathbb{E}\Big[ \sum_t r_t + \alpha \mathcal{H}(\pi(\cdot|s_t)) \Big],J(π)=E[∑t​rt​+αH(π(⋅∣st​))],﻿

so it learns smooth, exploratory policies.

  • Entropy: H(P)=Ex∼P[−log⁡P(x)].H(P) = \mathbb{E}_{x \sim P} [- \log P(x)].H(P)=Ex∼P​[−logP(x)].﻿ More diverse —> higher entropy.

SAC Training Flow

(1) Interact with the environment continuously

At every step:

  • Observe state sts_tst​﻿
  • Sample action at∼πϕ(a∣st)a_t \sim \pi_\phi(a|s_t)at​∼πϕ​(a∣st​)﻿
  • Execute ata_tat​﻿, get reward rtr_trt​﻿ and next state st+1s_{t+1}st+1​﻿
  • Store transition in replay buffer D={(st,at,rt,st+1,donet)}D = \{(s_t,a_t,r_t,s_{t+1},done_t)\}D={(st​,at​,rt​,st+1​,donet​)}﻿

So SAC never stops after an episode — it keeps collecting and updating asynchronously.

(2) Sample random minibatches from the replay buffer

At each training step (often every environment step):

(st,at,rt,st+1,donet)∼D(s_t, a_t, r_t, s_{t+1}, done_t) \sim D(st​,at​,rt​,st+1​,donet​)∼D﻿

Then you compute targets and update the networks.

(3) Critic (Q-function) update

SAC uses two critics Qθ1,Qθ2Q_{\theta_1}, Q_{\theta_2}Qθ1​​,Qθ2​​﻿ to avoid overestimation.

Target:

yt=rt+γ(1−donet) (min⁡iQθˉi(st+1,at+1′)−αlog⁡πϕ(at+1′∣st+1)),y_t = r_t + \gamma(1 - done_t)\, \Big( \min_i Q_{\bar\theta_i}(s_{t+1}, a'_{t+1}) - \alpha \log \pi_\phi(a'_{t+1}|s_{t+1}) \Big),yt​=rt​+γ(1−donet​)(mini​Qθˉi​​(st+1​,at+1′​)−αlogπϕ​(at+1′​∣st+1​)),﻿

where at+1′∼πϕ(⋅∣st+1)a'_{t+1} \sim \pi_\phi(\cdot|s_{t+1})at+1′​∼πϕ​(⋅∣st+1​)﻿

Critic loss:

LQ=E[(Qθi(st,at)−yt)2].L_Q = \mathbb{E}\big[(Q_{\theta_i}(s_t,a_t) - y_t)^2\big].LQ​=E[(Qθi​​(st​,at​)−yt​)2].﻿

(4) Actor (policy) update

Minimize:

Lπ=Es[αlog⁡πϕ(a∣s)−Qactor(s,a)],L_\pi = \mathbb{E}_s \big[ \alpha \log \pi_\phi(a|s) - Q_{actor}(s,a) \big],Lπ​=Es​[αlogπϕ​(a∣s)−Qactor​(s,a)],﻿

where a∼πϕ(a∣s)a \sim \pi_\phi(a|s)a∼πϕ​(a∣s)﻿, Qactor(s,a)=min⁡{Qθ1(s,a),Qθ2(s,a)}Q_{actor}(s,a) = \min\{Q_{\theta_1}(s,a), Q_{\theta_2}(s,a)\}Qactor​(s,a)=min{Qθ1​​(s,a),Qθ2​​(s,a)}﻿.

👉 This means the actor is encouraged to choose actions that:

  • have high Q-value (good performance),
  • and high entropy (diverse, exploratory).

So it’s both exploitation and exploration in one term.

(5) Temperature (α) update (important)

SAC automatically tunes the entropy weight α by minimizing:

Lα=Ea∼πϕ[−α(log⁡πϕ(a∣s)+Hˉ)],L_\alpha = \mathbb{E}_{a\sim\pi_\phi} \big[ -\alpha (\log \pi_\phi(a|s) + \bar{\mathcal{H}}) \big],Lα​=Ea∼πϕ​​[−α(logπϕ​(a∣s)+Hˉ)],﻿

so the agent maintains a target entropy level Hˉ\bar{\mathcal{H}}Hˉ﻿ (how “stochastic” we want the policy to be).

(6) Target network update

Just like DDPG/TD3:

θˉi←τθi+(1−τ)θˉi,\bar\theta_i \leftarrow \tau \theta_i + (1 - \tau)\bar\theta_i,θˉi​←τθi​+(1−τ)θˉi​,﻿

where τ≈0.005 is the Polyak averaging rate.

Main Updates:

Two critics (like TD3):

y=r+γmin⁡iQθˉi(s′,a′),a′∼πϕ(a′∣s′)y = r + \gamma \min_i Q_{\bar\theta_i}(s', a'), \quad a' \sim \pi_\phi(a'|s')y=r+γmini​Qθˉi​​(s′,a′),a′∼πϕ​(a′∣s′)﻿

Actor loss:

Lπ=Es[αlog⁡πϕ(a∣s)−Qθ(s,a)].L_\pi = \mathbb{E}_s [\alpha \log \pi_\phi(a|s) - Q_\theta(s,a)].Lπ​=Es​[αlogπϕ​(a∣s)−Qθ​(s,a)].﻿

It encourages actions that both have high Q and high entropy.

Entropy temperature α\alphaα﻿ can be learned automatically — balancing exploration and exploitation adaptively.

2. PPO - Proximal Policy Optimization

Goal

Learn a stochastic policy πθ(a∣s)\pi_\theta(a|s)πθ​(a∣s)﻿ that maximizes expected return while avoiding overly large policy updates.

1. Core idea

Instead of doing one big policy-gradient step (which can destabilize training), PPO keeps the new policy close to the old one by clipping the probability ratio:

rt(θ)=πθ(at∣st)πold(at∣st).r_t(\theta) = \frac{\pi_\theta(a_t|s_t)}{\pi_{\text{old}}(a_t|s_t)}.rt​(θ)=πold​(at​∣st​)πθ​(at​∣st​)​.﻿

2. PPO Loss

(a) Actor (Policy) Loss – Clipped Surrogate

Lactor=Et[min⁡(rt(θ) A^t,  clip(rt(θ),1−ϵ,1+ϵ) A^t)],L_{\text{actor}} = \mathbb{E}_t \Big[ \min \big( r_t(\theta)\, \hat{A}_t,\; \text{clip}(r_t(\theta), 1 - \epsilon, 1 + \epsilon)\, \hat{A}_t \big) \Big],Lactor​=Et​[min(rt​(θ)A^t​,clip(rt​(θ),1−ϵ,1+ϵ)A^t​)],﻿

  • A^t\hat{A}_tA^t​﻿: advantage estimate (from critic, often via GAE)
  • ϵ\epsilonϵ﻿: clip range (typically 0.1–0.2)
  • The min ensures you take the smaller gain between the unclipped and clipped ratio, preventing the policy from changing too much.

(b) Critic (Value Function) Loss

Lcritic=Et[(Vϕ(st)−Rttarget)2],L_{\text{critic}} = \mathbb{E}_t \big[ (V_\phi(s_t) - R_t^{\text{target}})^2 \big],Lcritic​=Et​[(Vϕ​(st​)−Rttarget​)2],﻿

  • Vϕ(st)V_\phi(s_t)Vϕ​(st​)﻿: critic’s prediction of return
  • Rttarget=A^t+Vϕ(st)R_t^{\text{target}} = \hat{A}_t + V_\phi(s_t)Rttarget​=A^t​+Vϕ​(st​)﻿ (or Monte-Carlo return)
  • It’s just a mean-squared error loss — no clipping here.
  • Updates the critic to better approximate the expected return.

(c) Entropy Bonus (for exploration)

Lentropy=Et[H(πθ(⋅∣st))],L_{\text{entropy}} = \mathbb{E}_t [ \mathcal{H}(\pi_\theta(\cdot|s_t)) ],Lentropy​=Et​[H(πθ​(⋅∣st​))],﻿

  • H(π)=−∫π(a∣s)log⁡π(a∣s)\mathcal{H}(\pi) = -\int \pi(a|s)\log \pi(a|s)H(π)=−∫π(a∣s)logπ(a∣s)﻿
  • Encourages the policy to remain stochastic early on (avoid premature convergence).

3. Combined PPO Objective

PPO minimizes the negative of total objective:

Ltotal(θ,ϕ)=−Lactor+cv Lcritic−ce Lentropy,L_{\text{total}}(\theta, \phi) = - L_{\text{actor}} + c_v\, L_{\text{critic}} - c_e\, L_{\text{entropy}},Ltotal​(θ,ϕ)=−Lactor​+cv​Lcritic​−ce​Lentropy​,﻿

with weighting constants, e.g.

cv=0.5c_v = 0.5cv​=0.5﻿, ce=0.01c_e = 0.01ce​=0.01﻿.

4. Training Loop (conceptual)

  1. Collect rollout using old policy πold\pi_{\text{old}}πold​﻿.
  1. Compute advantages A^t\hat{A}_tA^t​﻿ and targets RttargetR_t^{\text{target}}Rttarget​﻿.
  1. For a few epochs:
    • Recompute rt(θ)r_t(\theta)rt​(θ)﻿
    • Compute actor, critic, entropy losses
    • Backpropagate total loss
  1. Update parameters θ,ϕ\theta, \phiθ,ϕ﻿.
  1. Replace old policy with new one.
FeaturePPOSAC
Policy typeOn-policy (π_old vs π_new)Off-policy (replay buffer)
Data usageEach batch used once (must recollect)Reuse past transitions many times
Update frequencyAfter rollout batch (e.g. every 2k steps)Continuously (every step or multiple times per step)
EfficiencyLower (throw away data)Much higher (sample reuse)
ExplorationEntropy bonus in objectiveEntropy maximization as core principle
